THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
MailSource, LLC f/k/a Wild Geese, LLC, Respondent,
v.
M. A. Bailey & Associates, Inc., Michael A. Bailey and Linda Bailey,
Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
John Buford Grier, Special Circuit 
  Court Judge

Opinion No. 3688
Heard September 9, 2003 â€“ Filed November 
  3, 2001

REVERSED


  
    
      
Douglas F. Gay, of Rock Hill, for Appellants.
Stephen M. Cox, of Rock Hill, for Respondent.
      
    
  

STILWELL, J.:Â  MailSource, LLC, purchased 
  a direct mail processing business from M. A. Bailey & Associates, Inc.Â  
  Michael and Linda Bailey are the shareholders of M. A. Bailey (collectively 
  Bailey).Â  The asset purchase agreement contained a provision allowing either 
  party to demand arbitration of any dispute arising out of or relating to the 
  agreement.Â  Bailey appeals the trial courtâ€™s denial of its motion to compel 
  arbitration.Â  We reverse.Â  
FACTS
Pursuant to the agreement, MailSource 
  paid part of the purchase price at closing and executed a promissory note for 
  the rest.Â  As part of the transaction, Bailey also signed a consulting agreement 
  containing a non-compete clause.Â  The principal agreement required the parties 
  to attempt in good faith to settle any disputes first through consultation and 
  negotiation, and then by mediation.Â  If those attempts failed, the agreement 
  provided â€œeither party may demand that the dispute be arbitrated. . . .â€Â  
Bailey retained an affiliated business known as 
  List Right, which provided mailing lists to customers.Â  MailSource accused Bailey 
  of conducting activities through List Right that violated the non-compete clause 
  and also questioned certain financial information provided by Bailey prior to 
  the sale.Â  The parties exchanged letters regarding potential arbitration and 
  the procedures that would govern the arbitration, but could not agree.Â  
Bailey then filed an action against MailSource 
  alleging nonpayment of the promissory note.Â  The following day, MailSource filed 
  this action against Bailey seeking damages and injunctive relief for alleged 
  violations of the non-compete agreement, fraudulent inducement to enter into 
  the contract, and unfair trade practices.Â  Bailey moved to compel arbitration 
  on this action.Â  MailSource has made no motion to compel arbitration of Baileyâ€™s 
  action on the promissory note.Â  
In denying the motion to compel arbitration, the 
  trial court found Bailey waived the right to arbitrate by failing to agree to 
  proposals to arbitrate and by filing a lawsuit against MailSource.Â  In a motion 
  for reconsideration, Bailey argued MailSource had not proved it would be prejudiced 
  by requiring arbitration.Â  The trial court denied the motion, concluding that 
  Bailey inappropriately raised an issue in its 59(e) motion that could have been 
  initially presented.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In reviewing a circuit courtâ€™s decision regarding 
  a motion to stay an action pending arbitration, the determination of whether 
  a party â€œwaived its right to arbitrate is a legal conclusion subject to de 
  novo review; nevertheless, the circuit judgeâ€™s factual findings underlying 
  that conclusion will not be overruled if there is any evidence reasonably supporting 
  them.â€Â  Liberty Builders, Inc. v. Horton, 336 S.C. 658, 664-65, 521 S.E.2d 
  749, 753 (Ct. App. 1999).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Preservation Issue
MailSource contends whether it proved prejudice 
  is not properly before this court as Bailey did not raise the issue until the 
  motion for reconsideration.Â  We disagree. 
A party cannot raise 
  an issue for the first time in a Rule 59(e), SCRCP motion which could have been 
  raised at trial.Â  See, e.g., Commercial Credit Loans, Inc. v. Riddle, 
  334 S.C. 176, 186, 512 S.E.2d 123, 129 (Ct. App. 1999); Patterson v. Reid, 
  318 S.C. 183, 185, 456 S.E.2d 436, 437 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  However, the trial 
  court found that Bailey had waived its right to require arbitration by first 
  resorting to the courts.Â  The trial court did not, however, address the issue 
  of prejudice to MailSource.Â  Prejudice is a component that must be addressed 
  in determining whether waiver of arbitration has taken place.Â  In the motion 
  for reconsideration, Bailey merely asked the court to apply the appropriate 
  standard in making a finding of waiver.Â  Under these circumstances, it is appropriate 
  to request a court to review a ruling which the party contends fails to use 
  the proper standard.Â  Therefore, the issue is preserved for review by this court.Â  
  See Anonymous (M-156-90) v. State Bd. of Med. Examâ€™rs, 323 S.C. 
  260, 279-80, 473 S.E.2d 870, 880 (Ct. App. 1996), revâ€™d on other grounds, 
  329 S.C. 371, 496 S.E.2d 17 (1998).Â  
  II.              
Waiver â€“ Prejudice 
   
Bailey argues the trial court erred in finding 
  it waived the right to demand arbitration of the MailSource action by filing 
  a lawsuit.Â  Bailey contends MailSource has failed to demonstrate any prejudice 
  would result from compelling arbitration.Â  We agree.Â  
The right to enforce an arbitration clause may 
  be waived.Â  Hyload, Inc. v. Pre-Engineered Prods., Inc., 308 S.C. 
  277, 280, 417 S.E.2d 622, 624 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  â€œâ€˜Waiver is the voluntary and 
  intentional relinquishment of a known right.â€™â€Â  Liberty Builders, 336 
  S.C. at 665, 521 S.E.2d at 753.Â  

In order to establish waiver, a party must show prejudice 
  through an undue burden caused by delay in demanding arbitration.Â  Mere inconvenience 
  to an opposing party is not sufficient to establish prejudice.Â  There is no 
  set rule as to what constitutes a waiver of the right to arbitrate; the question 
  depends on the facts of each case.Â  Furthermore, it is the policy of this state 
  to favor arbitration of disputes.

Tolerâ€™s Cove Homeowners Assâ€™n v. Trident Constr. Co., 
  Op. No. 25713 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed Sept. 8, 2003) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 33 
  at 41, 46) (citations omitted).Â  In Sentry Engineering & Construction, 
  Inc. v. Marinerâ€™s Cay Development Corp., the supreme court stated, â€œit is 
  not inconsistency, but the presence or absence of prejudice which is determinative.Â  
  In this context prejudice is undue burden on the objecting party, brought about 
  by delay in the other partyâ€™s making its demand for arbitration.â€Â  287 S.C. 
  346, 351, 338 S.E.2d 631, 634 (1985) (citations omitted).Â  â€œâ€˜[W]aiver may not 
  be inferred from the fact that a party does not rely exclusively on the arbitration 
  provisions of a contract, but attempts to meet all issues raised in litigation 
  between it and another party to the agreement.â€™â€Â  Id. (quoting Germany 
  v. River Terminal Ry. Co., 477 F.2d 546, 547 (6th Cir. 1973)).Â  â€œOrdinarily, 
  however, bringing a suit based on the contract instead of relying on the arbitration 
  provision constitutes a waiver of the right to arbitrate.â€Â  Hyload, Inc., 
  308 S.C. at 280, 417 S.E.2d at 624.Â  â€œThis is simply a particular instance of 
  the general rule that acts inconsistent with the continued assertion of a right 
  may constitute waiver.â€Â  Id.  
In Sentry, Marinerâ€™s Cay asserted 
  Sentryâ€™s filing for an injunction was inconsistent with a right to arbitrate 
  and that the resulting prejudice to it constituted waiver.Â  Sentry, 287 
  S.C. at 351, 338 S.E.2d at 634.Â  â€œSentry counter[ed] that the petition for injunction 
  did not seek to litigate any issue raised by arbitration, but was simply an 
  attempt to correct work complained of by [Marinerâ€™s Cay].â€Â  Id.Â  The 
  court found â€œno prejudice by delay, only the inconvenience of litigating. . 
  . .â€Â  Id.Â  The court went on to find:Â  â€œSentry at all times sought to 
  enforce its right to arbitrate under the contract; it is clear it had no intention 
  to waive the right, and no waiver is shown.â€Â  Id.Â  
In Hyload, however, this court found waiver 
  of the right to arbitrate.Â  Hyload, Inc., 308 S.C. at 280, 417 S.E.2d 
  at 624.Â  In Hyload, Pre-Engineered refused to pay Hyloadâ€™s invoices after 
  it lost a job to a competitor â€œand sued Hyload for breach of its exclusive distributorship 
  agreement.Â  In turn, Hyload cancelled the distributorship agreement for nonpayment 
  of the invoices.â€Â  Id. at 279, 417 S.E.2d at 624.Â  

In response to Pre-Engineeredâ€™s suit, Hyload demanded arbitration 
  pursuant to the distributorship agreement.Â  Pre-Engineered agreed to arbitrate 
  and voluntarily dismissed the court action.Â  Pre-Engineered then prepared and 
  sent the arbitration documents to Hyload for its signature.Â  Hyload never signed 
  the documents.Â  Instead, it commenced a claim and delivery action under the 
  security agreement, recovering [materials and accounts receivable and then instituted 
  an] action to recover the remaining balance . . . plus attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Pre-Engineered 
  answered and reinstituted its original action for breach of the distributorship 
  agreement as a counterclaim.Â  

Id. at 279-280, 417 S.E.2d at 624.Â  This 
  court affirmed the trial courtâ€™s conclusion that Hyload waived its right to 
  arbitrate Pre-Engineeredâ€™s counterclaims due to its refusal to sign arbitration 
  papers and then initiating its own suit.Â  Id. at 280, 417 S.E.2d at 624.
In Liberty Builders, this court 
  again found waiver of the right to arbitrate where the party pursued active 
  litigation for two and a half years, sought the courtâ€™s assistance on numerous 
  occasions, and forced Horton to incur substantial costs and attorneyâ€™s fees, 
  waiting to demand arbitration until litigation was almost complete.Â  Liberty 
  Builders, 336 S.C. at 667-68, 521 S.E.2d at 754.Â  Liberty Builders required 
  Horton to answer the complaint and respond to discovery which would not have 
  been necessary in arbitration.Â  Id. at 665-66, 521 S.E.2d at 753.Â  In 
  Liberty Builders, the court focused on the amount of time and extensive 
  use of the judicial system.Â  Additionally, the court specifically noted the 
  finding of prejudice by the trial court and agreed that Horton was severely 
  prejudiced by Liberty Buildersâ€™ actions.Â  Id.Â  
There is no finding of prejudice to MailSource 
  in this case.Â  All parties agree MailSource needs to show prejudice for waiver 
  to exist.Â  Baileyâ€™s actions do not rise to the level found in Hyload 
  or Liberty Builders.Â  Bailey never induced MailSource to voluntarily 
  dismiss a lawsuit to pursue arbitration.Â  Additionally, Bailey exercised the 
  right to demand arbitration within twenty days of MailSource filing its lawsuit, 
  before even filing an answer.Â  There has been no substantial use of judicial 
  system resources, nor extensive requirements placed on MailSource as in Liberty 
  Builders.Â  MailSource admitted in oral arguments that the only prejudice, 
  given the time frame, was the two claims being considered separately.Â  
A significant feature of this case not present 
  in most arbitration cases is that the arbitration clause is not mandatory.Â  
  It is instead elective.Â  Either party may demand arbitration of a dispute but 
  neither is required to do so.Â  Indeed, MailSource acknowledged in oral argument 
  that it can demand arbitration of the lawsuit on the note, but candidly admitted 
  that it does not want to arbitrate either claim.Â  The only prejudice shown, 
  that of having claims arising from the same transaction resolved in different 
  forums, is therefore easily remedied; to the extent it is not remedied, any 
  prejudice is self-inflicted.
REVERSED.
HOWARD and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
MailSource, LLC f/k/a Wild Geese, LLC, Appellant,
v.
M. A. Bailey & Associates, Inc., Michael A. Bailey and Linda Bailey,
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
John Buford Grier, Special Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3689
Heard September 9, 2003 â€“ Filed November 
  3, 2003

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Stephen M. Cox, of Rock Hill, for Appellant.
Douglas F. Gay, of Rock Hill, for Respondents.
      
    
  

STILWELL, J.:Â  MailSource, LLC, purchased 
  a direct mail processing business from M. A. Bailey & Associates, the shareholders 
  of which are Michael and Linda Bailey (collectively, the Baileys).Â  In addition 
  to the asset purchase agreement, the parties entered into a consulting agreement 
  that included a non-compete clause.Â  MailSource appeals the denial of its motion 
  for an injunction seeking to restrain the Baileys from violating the non-compete 
  clause.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
The business bought by MailSource was 
  called â€œMail Rightâ€ by the Baileys.Â  The Baileys retained an affiliated business 
  called â€œList Right.â€Â  In addition to the asset purchase agreement and the consulting 
  agreement, the parties also entered into a supply agreement.Â  The supply agreement 
  defined â€œdirect mail processing services as:Â  all labeling, addressing, inserting, 
  sealing, sorting, bundling and delivery and directly related services provided 
  by Sellers and Mail Right Company prior to Closing Date.â€Â  

The non-compete clause in the consulting 
  agreement provides:
  
    
      (a) 
       Noncompetition.Â  [The Baileys] shall not 
  take any of the following actions during the applicable Noncompetition Period 
  (as defined below):
    
    
      
      (i)      Become employed by . . . involved or engaged in, 
  or otherwise commercially interested in or affiliated with . . . any person 
  or entity that competes with [MailSource] or an affiliate thereof (each, a â€œCompany 
  Affiliateâ€) in the business of direct mail processing services.
    
    
      
      (ii)Â Â Â  Solicit or attempt to solicit, for competitive purposes, 
  the business of any of the clients or customers of a Company Affiliate, or otherwise 
  induce such customers or clients or prospective customers or clients to reduce, 
  terminate, restrict or alter their business relationship with a Company Affiliate 
  in any fashion . . . .Â 
    
  

MailSource alleges the activities the Baileys conducted 
  through List Right violate the non-compete clause, pointing particularly to 
  its activities on behalf of Church of the Rock.Â  After MailSource purchased 
  Mail Right, the Baileys, through List Right, provided a mailing list to the 
  church sorted according to United States Postal Service requirements for receiving 
  bulk mail discounted rates.Â  They also provided the sorted list on mailing labels 
  and the paperwork required by the post office.Â  The only service not performed 
  was applying the labels to the mailings.Â  The Baileys through List Right provided 
  similar services to other customers.Â  Michael Bailey, President of List Right, 
  stated in an affidavit:Â 

The List Right business is not engaging in any activity 
  at the current time that it did not engage in prior to the sale of Mail Right 
  to [MailSource].Â  It is selling lists to customers, and providing those lists 
  to them in the format that the customer requests, which sometimes means providing 
  the list to customers on pre-sorted labels.Â  List Right is not doing any business 
  now that was formerly done by Mail Right when your affiant was President of 
  both. 

MailSource filed an action against the Baileys 
  seeking damages and injunctive relief for alleged violations of the agreement, 
  fraudulent inducement, and unfair trade practices.Â  MailSource asked for both 
  preliminary and permanent injunctive relief.Â  The trial court initially requested 
  a proposed order granting a preliminary injunction but then issued an order 
  denying a permanent injunction, finding that the pending appeal of the courtâ€™s 
  order denying arbitration divested it of jurisdiction.Â  Pursuant to MailSourceâ€™s 
  second motion for preliminary injunction, the trial court issued an order denying 
  it, stating:Â  â€œThe granting of said motion would alter the status quo during 
  the pendency of the appeal.â€Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
MailSource contends the trial court erred in refusing 
  to grant its motion for an injunction.Â  We find no abuse of discretion.Â  
â€œThe granting of temporary injunctive relief is 
  within the sound discretion of the trial court and will not be overturned absent 
  an abuse of that discretion.â€Â  City of Columbia v. Pic-A-Flick Video, Inc., 
  340 S.C. 278, 282, 531 S.E.2d 518, 520-21 (2000).Â  â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs 
  when a trial courtâ€™s decision is unsupported by the evidence or controlled by 
  an error of law.â€Â  County of Richland v. Simpkins, 348 S.C. 664, 668, 
  560 S.E.2d 902, 904 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  
To warrant a temporary injunction, the complaint 
  must allege facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action for injunction 
  and the information offered by both sides must demonstrate the injunction to 
  be reasonably necessary to protect the legal rights of the plaintiff pending 
  in the litigation.Â  Transcon. Gas Pipe Line Corp. v. Porter, 252 S.C. 
  478, 480-81, 167 S.E.2d 313, 315 (1969).Â  Generally, to obtain an injunction, 
  a party must demonstrate irreparable harm, a likelihood of success on the merits, 
  and an inadequate remedy at law.Â  Roach v. Combined Util. Commâ€™n, 290 
  S.C. 437, 442, 351 S.E.2d 168, 170 (Ct. App. 1986).Â  

It is well settled that, in determining whether a temporary 
  injunction should issue, the merits of the case are not to be considered, except 
  in so far as they may enable the court to determine whether a prima facie showing 
  has been made.Â  When a prima facie showing has been made entitling plaintiff 
  to injunctive relief, a temporary injunction will be granted without regard 
  to the ultimate termination of the case on the merits.Â  

Transcon., 252 S.C. at 481, 167 S.E.2d at 315.Â  â€œ[T]he 
  sole purpose of a temporary injunction is to preserve the status quo. . . .â€Â  
  Powell v. Immanuel Baptist Church, 261 S.C. 219, 221, 199 S.E.2d 60, 
  61 (1973).Â  â€œ[A] temporary injunction is [used] to preserve the subject of controversy 
  in the condition which it is at the time of the Order until opportunity is offered 
  for full and deliberate investigation and to preserve the existing status during 
  litigation. . . .â€Â  County Council of Charleston v. Felkel, 244 S.C. 
  480, 483-84, 137 S.E.2d 577, 578 (1964) (citations omitted).Â  â€œA temporary injunction 
  is made without prejudice to the rights of either party pending a hearing on 
  the merits, and when other issues are brought to trial, they are determined 
  without reference to the temporary injunction.â€Â  Helsel v. City of N. Myrtle 
  Beach, 307 S.C. 29, 32, 413 S.E.2d 824, 826 (1992).Â  The court should be 
  guided by general principles of equity:

First, the equities of both sides are to be considered, 
  and each case must be decided on its own particular facts.Â  Second, the court 
  of equity must â€œbalance the equitiesâ€ between the parties in determining what 
  if any relief to give.Â  The equities on both sides must be taken into account.Â  


Foreman v. Foreman, 280 S.C. 461, 464-65, 
  313 S.E.2d 312, 314 (Ct. App. 1984) (citations omitted).
â€œ[A] court can, and should, grant a preliminary 
  injunction in an arbitrable dispute whenever an injunction is necessary to preserve 
  the status quo pending arbitration.â€Â  Teradyne, Inc. v. Mostek Corp., 
  797 F.2d 43, 47 (1st Cir. 1986).Â  The fact that a court orders arbitration of 
  a dispute does not â€œabsolve [it] of its obligation to consider the merits of 
  a requested preliminary injunction.â€ Â Roso-Lino Bev. Distribs., Inc. v. Coca-Cola 
  Bottling Co. of New York, 749 F.2d 124, 125 (2d Cir. 1984). 
While we are troubled by the Baileysâ€™ continued 
  insistence they are able to conduct business which is strikingly similar to 
  the business they sold and with which they agreed not to compete, we agree with 
  the trial court that an injunction would alter the status quo.Â  MailSource apparently 
  knew that the retained List Right business was closely related, if not complementary, 
  to the business it purchased, having sought and received a right of first refusal 
  to purchase List Right if the Baileys decided to sell.Â  Additionally, Michael 
  Bailey states in his affidavit that List Right continues to conduct business 
  as it did before the sale.Â  
At least two other reasons buttress the trial courtâ€™s denial 
  of the injunction.Â  First, some of the covenants in the non-compete agreement 
  have already expired, and the remainder will soon expire.Â  While that does not 
  moot the issue, we must recognize the reality that any injunctive relief would 
  be short-lived under the terms of the non-compete clause.Â  MailSource invites 
  our attention to the law of other jurisdictions where courts have extended the 
  non-compete period following a breach to ensure the nonbreaching party receives 
  the benefit of the bargain.Â  We see no evidence this proposal was presented 
  to the trial court for its consideration, nor do we find support for it in South 
  Carolina law.Â  We therefore decline to adopt this procedure as a matter of first 
  impression, because to do so would essentially re-write the partiesâ€™ contract, 
  a service the courts of South Carolina do not perform.Â  See, e.g., Schulmeyer 
  v. State Farm Fire & Cas. Co., 353 S.C. 491, 495, 579 S.E.2d 132, 134 
  (2003) (courts do not rewrite contracts); Lewis v. Premium Inv. Corp., 
  351 S.C. 167, 171, 568 S.E.2d 361, 363 (2002) (same).Â  
Second, MailSource, in addition to seeking an 
  injunction, seeks and should be able to prove money damages from any breach 
  by the Baileys.Â  Cf. Skinner v. Elrod, 308 S.C. 239, 417 S.E.2d 
  599 (Ct. App. 1992) (breach of noncompetition clause was compensable in liquidated 
  damages).Â  An injunction is an equitable remedy; as such, it is available only 
  where no remedy at law exists or where the legal remedy would fail to make the 
  party whole.Â  

The general rule is that an injunction should be granted 
  only where some irreparable injury is threatened for which there is no adequate 
  remedy at law.Â  Whether a wrong is irreparable in the sense that equity may 
  intervene, and whether there is an adequate remedy at law for a wrong, are questions 
  that are not decided by narrow and artificial rules.

Cartee v. Lesley, 286 S.C. 249, 256, 333 S.E.2d 341, 
  345 (Ct. App. 1985) (citations omitted), cert. granted in part on other ground 
  and decision affâ€™d, 290 S.C. 333, 350 S.E.2d 388 (1986); see also 
  Knohl v. Duke Power Co., 260 S.C. 374, 376, 196 S.E.2d 115, 116 (1973) 
  (holding that a â€œcomplaint fails to state a cause of action for injunctive relief 
  unless facts are alleged which show that the plaintiff has no adequate and complete 
  remedy at lawâ€).
Based on the specific facts of this case, we find 
  it is a close question whether a preliminary injunction should issue.Â  However, 
  we are unable to say the trial court abused its discretion in refusing to alter 
  the status quo by restricting the Baileysâ€™ activities.Â  See Simpkins, 
  348 S.C. at 668, 560 S.E.2d at 904.Â  
AFFIRMED.
HOWARD and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Thomas Bryant Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Mark H. Westbrook, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3690
Heard May 14, 2003 â€“ Filed November 
  3, 2003

AFFIRMED 


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, of the SC Appellate 
  Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, 
  Assistant Attorney General Derrick K. McFarland, all of Columbia; and Solicitor 
  Warren Blair Giese, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


HOWARD, J.:Â  Thomas Bryant was convicted 
  of murder and unlawful possession of a firearm.Â  The circuit court sentenced 
  him to life imprisonment without parole for murder and five years for possession 
  of the firearm, to run concurrently.Â  Bryant appeals, arguing the circuit court 
  erred by admitting evidence of his prior bad acts and convictions.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Bryant is a paraplegic who was staying at a Days 
  Inn Hotel (â€œthe Hotelâ€) in Columbia, South Carolina.Â  Bryant met Daniel Austin 
  at a nearby nightclub.Â  
At approximately 3:30 a.m. on July 23, 1999, Austin 
  left the nightclub with Bryant.Â  Nellie Connell, the front desk attendant at 
  the Hotel, observed Austin and Bryant together at approximately 3:30 a.m., and 
  Austin was pushing Bryant in his wheelchair.Â  According to Connell, Austin subsequently 
  came to the front desk and requested a key to Bryantâ€™s room.Â  Connell gave Austin 
  a key to Bryantâ€™s room. 
Between 3:30 a.m. and 4:00 a.m., Kevin Hawkins, 
  a guest at the Hotel, observed Bryant in the Hotel hallway.Â  Bryant had a scrape 
  on his nose and his pants were in his lap.Â  Bryant told Hawkins he had been 
  beaten and asked Hawkins to go to the front desk and ask for help. Hawkins went 
  to the front desk and spoke to Connell, and Connell indicated she would call 
  the authorities.Â  As Connell was telephoning the police, she heard gunshots. 

When the police arrived, Austin was lying in the 
  breezeway bleeding from gunshot wounds, and Bryant was in his hotel room firing 
  a gun through the door.Â  After a standoff lasting approximately twenty minutes, 
  officers heard one final shot.Â  The officers entered Bryantâ€™s room and found 
  Bryant on the floor with a self-inflicted gunshot wound to his stomach.Â  Austin 
  died from his gunshot wounds.Â  
Following a jury trial, Bryant was convicted for 
  murdering Austin and for unlawfully possessing a firearm.Â  He was sentenced 
  to life imprisonment without parole for murder and five years for possession 
  of the firearm, the sentences to run concurrently.Â  Bryant appeals.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Â Â Â Â Â  Prior Bad Acts
Bryant argues the circuit court erred in admitting 
  testimony about Bryantâ€™s prior bad acts.Â  We disagree.
â€œThe admission or exclusion of evidence is left 
  to the sound discretion of the trial judge, whose decision will not be reversed 
  on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.â€ State v. Saltz, 346 S.C. 114, 
  121, 551 S.E.2d 240, 244 (2001). Furthermore, the admission of reply testimony 
  is within the trial courtâ€™s discretion, and a reviewing court will not find 
  an abuse of discretion â€œif the testimony is arguably contradictory of and in 
  reply to earlier testimony.â€Â  State v. Todd, 290 S.C. 212, 214, 349 S.E.2d 
  339, 340 (1986).
During direct examination in the stateâ€™s case, 
  John Campbell testified he first encountered Bryant at the nightclub a few days 
  before the night of Austinâ€™s murder.Â  Campbell was the bouncer for the club, 
  and he stated he kept a â€œclose eyeâ€ on Bryant on the night of the murder.Â  
Campbellâ€™s testimony indicated Austin was not combative 
  toward Bryant on the evening of the murder.Â  Campbell testified Bryant arrived 
  at the nightclub on the night of the murder between 8:00 p.m. and 8:30 p.m.Â  
  Somewhere around 11:00 p.m., Austin entered the nightclub, and shortly thereafter, 
  Bryant and Austin were â€œvery chummy, [and] real friendly toward each other.â€Â Â  
  Between 3:15 a.m. and 3:30 a.m., Austin and Bryant attempted to leave the nightclub, 
  whereupon Bryant fell out of his wheelchair and required assistance by both 
  Campbell and Austin to get back in his chair.Â  Bryant and Austin then left the 
  nightclub.Â  
During cross-examination, Bryantâ€™s counsel attacked 
  Campbellâ€™s independent ability to remember the events of the night of the murder, 
  implying his recollection had been supplemented by his pre-trial discussions 
  with the solicitor.Â  
During re-direct examination, the solicitor 
  sought to introduce testimony from Campbell that Bryant had threatened Campbell 
  during their first encounter to explain why Campbell had maintained a close 
  eye on Bryant on the night of the murder.Â  Over Bryantâ€™s objection, the court 
  allowed Campbellâ€™s testimony, ruling evidence that Bryant had previously threatened 
  Campbell was relevant to establish Campbellâ€™s basis for focusing on Bryant on 
  the night in question.Â  In doing so, the court provided the following limiting 
  charge to the jury: â€œNow, there was also testimony in the case about conduct 
  of a defendant toward a witness in the case.Â  That testimony was introduced 
  in regard to the credibility of the witness who gave it and must not be considered 
  against the character of the defendant.â€ 
Viewing the testimony in light of our standard 
  of review, we conclude there was no abuse of discretion in the admission of 
  this evidence.Â  Bryant specifically attacked Campbellâ€™s credibility as to his 
  observation of Bryant and Austin, implying Campbellâ€™s memory had been supplemented 
  by the solicitor because he had no reason in a crowded bar to pay close attention 
  to Bryant or Austin on the night of the murder.Â  Campbellâ€™s redirect testimony 
  was relevant on this credibility issue.Â  The solicitor was entitled to introduce 
  testimony â€œarguably contradictory of and in reply to earlier testimonyâ€ to strengthen 
  Campbellâ€™s credibility once attacked.Â  Todd, 290 S.C. at 214, 349 S.E.2d 
  at 340.Â  Therefore, Bryantâ€™s argument is without merit.
II. Â Â Â Â  Prior Convictions
Bryant argues the circuit court erred by admitting 
  impeachment evidence of his prior firearms convictions because the prejudicial 
  effect of the convictions outweighed their probative value.Â  
The admission of prior convictions to impeach the 
  credibility of a defendant is a matter within the sound discretion of the trial 
  court, and thus, its decision will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse 
  of discretion.Â  Green v. State, 338 S.C. 428, 433, 527 S.E.2d 98, 101 
  (2000).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when the conclusions of the circuit court 
  either lack evidentiary support or are controlled by an error of law.Â  State 
  v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 5-6, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001).
Rule 609(a)(1) provides prior convictions can be 
  used to impeach the accused when: 1) the crime was punishable by death or imprisonment 
  in excess of one year, and 2) the court determines the probative value of admitting 
  the evidence outweighs its prejudicial effect.Â Â  Rule 609(a)(1), SCRE.Â Â  
In weighing the probative value of prior convictions, 
  the circuit court should consider all relevant factors including but not limited 
  to the following:Â  â€œ1) the impeachment value of the prior crime; 2) the point 
  in time of the conviction and the witnessâ€™s subsequent history; 3) the similarity 
  between the past crime and the charged crime; 4) the importance of the defendant's 
  testimony; and 5) the centrality of the credibility issue.â€Â  State v. Colf, 
  337 S.C. 622, 627, 525 S.E.2d 246, 248 (1998); Green, 338 S.C. at 433, 
  527 S.E.2d at 101.
Prior to Bryantâ€™s testimony, the solicitor 
  indicated he intended to impeach Bryant with evidence of prior convictions including 
  voluntary manslaughter in 1987, possession of a firearm in 1997, and pointing 
  and presenting a firearm in 1998.Â  The circuit court first analyzed whether 
  to admit the voluntary manslaughter conviction using the Colf factors.Â  
  The circuit court refused to admit the conviction, ruling the probative value 
  of the conviction was outweighed by the prejudicial effect.Â  In so ruling, the 
  circuit court made the following analysis: 

I think there is some substantial impeachment value to it 
  . . . as . . . almost every two years various things that have come up with 
  the defendant.Â  And of course, the point in time, obviously, still works against 
  allowing it, that was 16 years ago.Â  The third factor, the similarity between 
  the two, is obviously significant . . . [for probative value] . . . . But 
  itâ€™s also extremely significant for the value of prejudice that it brings into 
  the issue.Â  As far as the importance of the defendantâ€™s testimony . . . it is 
  important.Â  [Bryantâ€™s defense witnesses] didnâ€™t help his case too much . . . 
  . [Additionally,] the credibility issue is central.

(emphasis added).Â  
However, the circuit court did admit Bryantâ€™s convictions 
  for possession of an unlawful weapon in 1997 and pointing and presenting in 
  1998, ruling as follows:

[The other two convictions] are both over a year old, 
  well within the 10-year period, and frankly, do indicate within themselves consistency 
  as well as when considered with the manslaughter conviction . . . . And 
  I realize certainly . . . [the] prejudicial issue related to these, but frankly, 
  I think under those circumstances the probative value does substantially outweigh 
  the prejudice that could be directed from the toward the defendant from it. 
  . . . [Furthermore,] the fact that he may tend to get in trouble from time to 
  time, while it has a certain amount of prejudice in it, also, does include that 
  issue of whether or not heâ€™s worthy of belief.

(emphasis added).
Bryant contends this analysis, combined 
  with the statements made during the circuit courtâ€™s voluntary manslaughter analysis, 
  demonstrates the circuit court admitted the prior convictions based on the improvident 
  belief the evidence was admissible to demonstrate propensity.
Although, viewed in isolation, the statements 
  made by the circuit court could be construed to indicate the circuit court allowed 
  the evidence to prove propensity, we must view the circuit courtâ€™s statements 
  as a whole to determine its reasoning.Â  See State v. Evans, 354 
  S.C. 579, 584, 582 S.E.2d 407, 410 (2003).
Reviewing the circuit courtâ€™s statements as a whole 
  reveals the circuit court allowed the testimony based on its belief the testimony 
  could lead to an inference Bryant was unworthy of credibility because of his 
  prior convictions.Â  This is an appropriate reason to admit prior convictions.Â  
  See Green, 338 S.C. at 433, 527 S.E.2d at 101 (holding, under 
  certain circumstances, admitting prior, similar convictions is appropriate to 
  impeach the credibility of a defendant).
Furthermore, evidence exists within the record 
  to support the circuit courtâ€™s decision to admit the evidence.[1] Â  
The state presented evidence indicating Bryant 
  possessed the requisite intent for murder.Â  In response, Bryant introduced the 
  testimony of Johnny Stapleton, intending to demonstrate Bryant shot Austin in 
  self-defense. 
Although Stapleton could 
  not remember giving the police a statement on the night of the murder because 
  he was â€œhighly intoxicated,â€ he acknowledged a statement bearing his signature 
  in which he indicated Austin, the victim, was intoxicated and demonstrated violent 
  behavior on the night of the murder.Â  Bryant then testified in his defense, 
  asserting he shot Austin in self-defense.Â  The state sought to introduce evidence 
  of Bryantâ€™s prior convictions to impeach his credibility.Â  After analyzing the 
  Colf factors and conducting a meaningful analysis pursuant to South Carolina 
  Rules of Evidence, Rule 609(a)(1), the circuit court admitted the evidence of 
  prior convictions.Â  
Viewing the evidence in light of our standard of 
  review, the record indicates Bryant and Austin were the only people present 
  when the shooting occurred.Â  Additionally, the only other defense witness, Stapleton, 
  did not remember the events of the night of the murder.Â  Thus, Bryantâ€™s defense 
  is essentially predicated upon his version of the facts.Â  Furthermore, the convictions 
  were not stale.Â  Rather, the convictions were fairly close in temporal proximity 
  to the charged offense.Â  
Given the importance of Bryantâ€™s testimony to his 
  defense, and the stateâ€™s burden of discounting his testimony to prove the elements 
  of murder, we hold the circuit court, having conducted a Colf analysis, 
  was within its discretion to admit Bryantâ€™s prior convictions to impeach his 
  credibility.
In so holding, we note, our supreme court has cautioned 
  the bench and bar that admitting prior convictions similar to the charged offenses 
  is inherently prejudicial and should only be done rarely.Â  See Colf, 
  337 S.C. at 622, 525 S.E.2d at 246 (â€œ[E]vidence of similar offenses inevitably 
  suggests to the jury the defendantâ€™s propensity to commit the crime with which 
  he is charged.Â  This risk is not eliminated by limiting instructions.Â  Therefore 
  . . . â€˜evidence of any similar offense should be admitted only rarely . . . 
  .â€™â€) (quoting United States v. Beahm, 664 F.2d 414, 419 (4th Cir. 1981)).Â  
  However, where, as here, the circuit court has conducted the appropriate analysis 
  and evidence exists to support its ruling, we decline to disturb that ruling.
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, Bryantâ€™s convictions are 

AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, J., concurs.
BEATTY, J., dissents in a separate opinion.
BEATTY, J:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  I respectfully dissent.Â  I believe 
  the trial judge erred in the admission of defendantâ€™s prior convictions for 
  possession of an unlawful weapon, and pointing and presenting a firearm.Â  The 
  prejudicial effect clearly outweighed the probative value of these prior convictions. 
  The trial court admitted the prior convictions solely because the crimes indicated 
  a tendency to get in trouble. The trial courtâ€™s reasoning amounted to prohibited 
  character evidence under 404(b), SCRE. 
A fundamental principle of our criminal jurisprudence 
  is that an accused shall only be tried on the offense charged, indicted, and 
  currently before the court.Â  Thus, the courts, state and federal, closely scrutinize 
  the admission of prior convictions of the accused.Â  See Green v. State, 
  338 S.C. 428, 433, 527 S.E.2d 98, 101 (2000).Â  As a result, similar prior convictions 
  are not per se inadmissible; however, they are generally excluded. 
  [2] Â  
In Green v. State, our supreme court opined, 
  â€œadmission of evidence of a similar offense often does little to impeach the 
  credibility of a testifying defendant while undoubtedly prejudicing him.Â  The 
  jury, despite limiting instructions, can hardly avoid drawing the inference 
  that the past conviction suggests some probability that defendant committed 
  the similar offense for which he is currently charged.â€ 338 S.C. at 434, 527 
  S.E.2d at 101 (quoting United States v. Beahm, 664 F.2d 414, 418-419 
  (4th Cir. 1981)).Â  The Green court set forth factors to be 
  considered when weighing probative value against prejudicial effect.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
The Green court provided the following factors for 
  consideration when determining whether to admit evidence:

  
    
       1. 
       The impeachment value of the 
  prior crimes.
    
    
       2.  
      The point in time of the
        conviction and the witnessesâ€™ subsequent history.
    
    
       3. 
       The similarity between the past 
  crime and the crime charged.
    
    
       4.
       The importance of the defendantâ€™s 
  testimony.
    
    
       5. 
       The centrality of the credibility 
  issue.
    
  

Id.; see also State v. Colf, 
  337 S.C. 622, 525 S.E.2d 246 (2000).
Here, the trial court considered the Colf factors 
  when in determining whether to allow the manslaughter conviction into evidence.Â  
  Notwithstanding the trial courtâ€™s Colf analysis of the prior manslaughter 
  conviction, the record does not clearly reflect similar treatment of the two 
  additional prior convictions.Â Â  In fact, the record only reflects an indirect 
  consideration of 609 (a)(1), and (b) SCRE, absent the required Colf considerations, 
  as it relates to these prior convictions.
During the colloquy on the admissibility of the 
  prior convictions the trial court stated:

And, of course, the credibility issue is central.Â  I think 
  when it comes down to it, in order for the jury to be able to see the credibility 
  of this defendant as well as any other witness, they should be able to see all 
  of these, but itâ€™s probably risky to let that in.Â  So Iâ€™m going to have to rule 
  that the manslaughter conviction would not be allowed to be used.
However, the other two convictions, no question, would be 
  allowed to be used.Â  They are both over a year old, well within the 10-year 
  period and, frankly, do indicate within themselves consistency as well as when 
  considered with the manslaughter conviction.Â  So I donâ€™t think thereâ€™s any question 
  that all of them do.
And I realize certainly, Mr. Strickler, that prejudicial 
  issue related to these, but, frankly, I think under those circumstances the 
  probative value does substantially outweigh the prejudice that could be directed 
  toward the defendant from it.Â  So with that in mind, Iâ€™m going to allow the 
  convictions that have been requested within the 10-year period but not the manslaughter 
  conviction.

The trial court further stated:

[I]t comes down to whether or not you present these to the 
  jury to let them decide whether they consider the defendant worthy of belief 
  or how much his worthiness of belief is affected by these convictions.
And the fact that he may tend to get in trouble from time 
  to time, while it has a certain amount of prejudice in it, also, does include 
  that issue of whether or not heâ€™s worthy of belief.

It is clear that the trial judge did not properly 
  consider the Colf factors.Â  It appears that the trial judge improperly 
  concluded that significant probative value exist merely because of the similarity 
  of the crimes.Â  Absent more, the courtâ€™s reasoning is erroneous.Â  
The prior convictions involved possession and pointing a 
  gun, the current charge involves the use of a gun in a homicide.Â  The prejudicial 
  effect is inescapable.Â  Further, it is evident that the trial courtâ€™s conclusion 
  that the probative value of the prior convictions outweighed the prejudicial 
  effect was based upon the courtâ€™s belief that the prior convictions, when considered 
  with the manslaughter conviction, indicated that the defendant had a tendency 
  to get in trouble.Â  That tendency to get in trouble raised the issue of whether 
  the defendant is worthy of belief.Â  The foregoing amounts to no more than impermissible 
  character evidence. 404(b), SCRE.
The defendant claimed self-defense.Â  The record 
  does not reflect overwhelming contrary evidence of his guilt; the only witnesses 
  to the homicide were the defendant and the deceased.Â  The defendantâ€™s testimony 
  was important and his credibility was a central issue in the case.Â  The prior 
  convictions were an attack on the defendantâ€™s character and yielded very little 
  if any impeachment value.Â  Absent impeachment value, there is no probative value 
  in the admission of the prior convictions in this case.Â  Therefore, I would 
  reverse the trial courtâ€™s ruling.

 
   
    [1]  Both the conviction for possession of a firearm and the conviction 
    for pointing and presenting a firearm are punishable by imprisonment in excess 
    of one year.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-23-30(e) (2003) (stating it is 
    unlawful for any person who has been convicted of a violent crime to possess 
    a pistol); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-1-90(F) (2003) (stating possession of a pistol 
    by a person convicted of a violent crime is a Class F felony); S.C. Code Ann. 
    Â§ 16-1-20(A) (6) (2003) (stating a Class F felony is punishable by not more 
    than five-years imprisonment); See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-23-410 (2003) 
    (stating the crime of pointing and presenting a firearm is a felony punishable 
    by not more than five-years imprisonment).Â  Thus, we limit our analysis to 
    whether the circuit court abused its discretion in its application of the 
    Colf factors.Â  See Rule 609(a)(1), SCRE (stating prior convictions 
    can be used to impeach the accused when: 1) the crime was punishable by death 
    or imprisonment in excess of one year, and 2) the court determines the probative 
    value of admitting the evidence outweighs its prejudicial effect); Colf, 
    337 S.C. at 627, 525 S.E.2d at 248 (holding in weighing the probative value 
    of prior convictions, the circuit court should consider all relevant factors 
    including but not limited to the following:Â  â€œ1) the impeachment value of 
    the prior crime; 2) the point in time of the conviction and the witnessâ€™s 
    subsequent history; 3) the similarity between the past crime and the charged 
    crime; 4) the importance of the defendantâ€™s testimony; and 5) the centrality 
    of the credibility issue.â€).Â  

 
   [2]  â€œWe decline to hold similar prior convictions 
    inadmissible in all cases.Â  Trial Courts must weigh the probative value of 
    the prior conviction against their prejudicial effect to the accused.Â  In 
    the special case, where the prior conviction is for the same offense as that 
    for which the defendant is being tried, the trial court generally will not 
    permit the government to prove the nature of the offenseâ€¦[it] would amount 
    to unfair prejudice.â€ Green, 338 S.C. at 433 n.5, 527 S.E.2d at 101 
    n.5 (internal citation omitted).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals

 
   
     
       
        Alice C. G. Perry, Emily Mitchell, 
          Eliza Tremble, and Doris Green, Respondents,
        v.
        Heirs at Law and Distributees of Charles 
          Gadsden, C.H. Gadsden, Cecil S. Gadsden, C.S. Gadsden, Louise Gadsden, 
          Cain Gadsden, John Gadsden, Lula Nelson, Louis Gadsden, Herman Gadsden, 
          Carrie Gadsden, Estella Gadsden, Mattie Gadsden, United States Department 
          of Agriculture, Farmers Home Administration, South Carolina Electric 
          and Gas, Hazel Point Partnership, Luther Major, Martha Major, Queenie 
          Taylor, Dolly Fripp, Beaufort-Jasper Comprehensive Health Services, 
          Inc., also, the following persons believed to be living, Cecil J. Gaston, 
          Jr. a/k/a Cecil J. Gaston, Cornelius Gaston a/k/a Cornelius Gadsen, 
          Herman Gaston, Lisa Roacher, Linda Mason, Herbert Mason, Willis Gaston, 
          and Louise Gaston a/k/a Louise Gadson, and all heirs at law, devisees, 
          or persons unknown claiming by, under or through any of the above-named 
          persons, John Doe or Mary Roe, being fictitious names designating a 
          class of persons, or a legal entity, infants, incompetents, persons 
          in the military service, if any, known or unknown, who may be an heir, 
          distributee, devisee, legatee, issuee, aliente, administrator, executor, 
          creditor, successor or assign having or claiming to have any right, 
          title, interest, estate in or lien upon the real estate described in 
          the Complaint herein, Defendants,
        of whom Heirs at Law and Distributees 
          of Charles Gadsden, C.H. Gadsden, Louise Gadsden, Cain Gadsden, John 
          Gadsden, Lula Nelson, Louis Gadsden, Herman Gadsden, Estella Gadsden, 
          Mattie Gadsden are the Appellants.
      
    
  

 
  
  Appeal From Beaufort County
    Thomas Kemmerlin, Master In Equity for Beaufort County
  
  Opinion No. 3691
    Submitted October 6, 2003 â€“ Filed November 3, 2003
  
  AFFIRMED
    


 
   
     
       
         
          Mary P. Miles, of West Columbia, for Appellants.
        
      
    
  

 
   
     
       
         
          Louis O. Dore, Cheryl V. Doe and 
            Thomas A. Holloway, all of Beaufort, for Respondents.
        
      
    
  

 
  
  PER CURIAM:Â  More than four years 
    after the master-in-equity ordered the partition of the 110.54-acre tract 
    of land at the heart of this litigation, Gadsden filed a Rule 60(b), SCRCP 
    motion to set aside the partition order, alleging fraud on the court and inequitable 
    prospective application of the order.Â  The trial court denied the motion.Â  
    Gadsden appeals.Â  We affirm.
  FACTS AND PROCEDURAL HISTORY 
  
  On February 13, 1990, Alice C.G. Perry, Emily 
    Mitchell, Eliza Tremble, and Doris Green ("Respondents") brought 
    an action against their uncle Cecil J. Gadsden, Jr. and the heirs of their 
    grandfather Cecil J. Gadsden, Sr. (collectively "Gadsden"), seeking 
    the partition of 110.54 acres of land occupied by Cecil J. Gadsden, Jr. (Cecil, 
    Jr.), as well as punitive damages and an accounting.Â  (R. at 3.)Â  The master 
    determined the various heirs' interests in the property and awarded $100 in 
    punitive damages, finding Cecil, Jr., had defrauded the heirs.Â  The master 
    ordered the parties to devise a partition plan within thirty days.Â  When the 
    parties failed to produce a plan, the master ordered a public sale of the 
    property.
  Gadsden appealed, and this court held that 
    the master correctly found that Gadsden had defrauded the heirs, but ruled 
    that the property should have been partitioned in kind rather than sold.Â  
    Perry v. Heirs at Law & Distributees of Gadsden, 313 S.C. 296, 
    437 S.E.2d 174 (Ct. App. 1993). After granting Gadsden's petition for certiorari, 
    the Supreme Court of South Carolina affirmed our decision and remanded to 
    the master to partition in kind.Â  Perry v. Heirs at Law & Distributees 
    of Gadsden, 316 S.C. 224, 449 S.E.2d 250 (1994).
  On remand, the master entered a judgment 
    against Cecil, Jr. and in favor of ten respondents in the amount ofÂ  $151,146.27. 
    Cecil, Jr. appealed again asserting that he had been wrongfully denied credit 
    against the judgment for certain timber cultivation expenses and distributions 
    to the heirs over the years.Â  We affirmed the master's decision in an unpublished 
    opinion.
  To effectuate the partition mandated by our decision, 
    partition commissioners were appointed by the master.Â  The court empowered 
    the commissioners to hire surveyors and appraisers as needed.Â  (R. at 25.)Â Â  
    In determining the appropriate division of the property, the commissioners 
    considered, inter alia, the testimony of a licensed appraiser that 
    the fair market value of the property was $354,000.00 as of February 9, 1995. 
    (R. at 32.)Â  Using this value as a starting point, the commissioners adjusted 
    the value of the property to coincide with the increase in value of other 
    properties in the immediate vicinity over the previous two years.Â  (R. at 
    33.)Â  Adopting a per annum increase of ten percent, the commissioners determined 
    the current fair market value of the property to be $424,800.00.Â  (R. at 33.) 
    Based on the commissioners' report, the master entered an order in partition 
    on February 20, 1998 that left Gadsden with title to 4.26 acres of the 110.54 
    acre tract.Â  (R. at 37-39.)
  More than four years after the 1998 partition 
    order was entered, Gadsden filed a motion to reopen the judgment pursuant 
    to Rule 60(b), SCRCP, asserting the $424,800.00 value assigned to the property 
    by the commissioners was "so incorrect as to amount to fraud upon the 
    Court." (R. at 61.)Â  By order dated May 3, 2002, the trial court denied Gadsden's 
    motion.Â  This appeal followed.

 
 
  STANDARD OF REVIEW
  A party seeking to set aside a judgment pursuant 
    to Rule 60(b) has the burden of presenting evidence entitling him to the requested 
    relief.Â  Bowers v. Bowers, 304 S.C. 65, 67, 403 S.E.2d 127, 129 (1991).Â  
    Whether to grant or deny a motion under Rule 60(b) is within the sound discretion 
    of the trial judge.Â  Coleman v. Dunlap, 306 S.C. 491, 494, 413 S.E.2d 
    15, 17 (1992).Â  On review, we are limited to determining whether the trial 
    court abused its discretion in granting or denying such a motion.Â  Saro 
    Invs. v. Ocean Holiday P'ship, 314 S.C. 116, 441 S.E.2d 835, 840 (Ct. 
    App. 1994). 

 
  LAW/ANALYSIS
  I. Â Fraud Upon The Court

 
  Although other motions to reopen judgments 
    based on fraud must be filed within a year of the judgment or order, Rule 
    60(b) allows a party to seek relief from an order for "fraud upon the 
    court" after the expiration of one year. Fraud upon the court is a narrow 
    and invidious species of fraud that "subvert[s] the integrity of the 
    Court itself, or is a fraud perpetrated by officers of the court so that the 
    judicial machinery cannot perform in the usual manner its impartial task of 
    adjudging cases that are presented for adjudication." Chewning v. 
    Ford Motor Co., 354 S.C. 72, 78, 579 S.E.2d 605, 608 (2003).Â  Like all 
    other types of fraud, proving fraud upon the court requires showing that the 
    perpetrator acted with the intent to defraud, for there is no such thing as 
    accidental fraud.Â  See Chewning, 354 S.C. at 78, 579 S.E.2d 
    at 608 ("'Fraud upon the court,' whatever else it embodies, requires 
    a showing that one has acted with an intent to deceive or defraud the court."); 
    Black's Law Dictionary 660 (6th ed. 1990) ("As distinguished from negligence, 
    [fraud] is always positive, intentional.").
  Here, Gadsden's failings are several.Â  First, 
    Gadsden has not met his burden of showing fraudulent intent.Â  In fact, Gadsden 
    has failed to even allege the existence of fraudulent intent.Â  Instead, Gadsden 
    merely states that the "appraised value of $424,800.00 as applied by the commissioners 
    to the realty in question is grossly insufficient and seriously understates 
    the actual value of the property."  (R. at 59.)Â  Even if the value applied 
    by the commissioners understated the property's value, any undervaluation 
    would not amount to fraud unless the commissioners adopted the value with 
    fraudulent intent. GadsdenÂ  has failed to assert this is the case.Â  Moreover, 
    nothing in the record suggests thatÂ  the commissioners acted fraudulently.
  Gadsden has not supported his charge of insufficiency 
    of value with anything of an evidentiary nature.Â  Gadsden has neither asserted 
    what the "actual value of the property" is, nor offered affidavits in support 
    of such an assertion.Â  To this end, Gadsden has asked this Court to take judicial 
    notice of the landâ€™s appreciation in value to support his claim. This, we 
    cannot do. Gadsden cannot escape his burden of establishing the essential 
    elements of fraud by passing that duty to the court. We hold Gadsden's allegation 
    of insufficiency of valueÂ  is so deficient that we would be compelled to find 
    the trial court abused its discretion had it granted his motion.
  II.Â  Inequitable Prospective Application
  Rule 60(b)(5), SCRCP, provides that judgments 
    may be set aside if "the judgment has been satisfied, released, or discharged, 
    or a prior judgment upon which it has been based has been reversed or otherwise 
    vacated, or it is no longer equitable that the judgment should have prospective 
    application." Rule 60(b)(5) is based on the historical power ofÂ  a court of 
    equity to modify its decree â€œin light of subsequent conditions.â€ Mr. G 
    v. Mrs. G, 320 S.C. 305, 311, 465 S.E.2d 101, 107 (Ct. App. 1995). Gadsden 
    asserts that this case fits under the "prospective application" language of 
    the Rule.Â  We disagree.
  First, although motions under 60(b)(5) are 
    not subject to the requirement that they be filed within one year of the judgment, 
    they still must be filed within a reasonable time. Evans v. Gunter, 
    294 S.C. 525, 528, 366 S.E.2d 44, 46 (Ct. App. 1988). While we are reluctant 
    to proclaim that four years is a per se unreasonable period of time, Gadsden, 
    who bore the burden of showing the propriety of his motion, has failed to 
    proffer an argument as to why we should find that a four-year delay is reasonable 
    in this case. [1] Â  We therefore affirm the trial courtâ€™s 
    holding that Gadsden's 60(b)(5) motion is untimely.
  Second, a ruling that a partition order has 
    prospective application would be inappropriate and an affront to the commonly 
    understood meaning of the term "prospective application."  The test typically 
    appliedÂ  to determine whether an order has prospective application is "whether 
    it is executory or involves supervision of changing conduct or conditions 
    by the court." Saro Invs. v. Ocean Holiday P'ship, 314 S.C. 116, 120, 
    441 S.E.2d 835, 838 n.3 (Ct. App. 1994).Â  For example, injunctions ordinarily 
    have prospective application.Â  See, e.g., Binkley v. Rabon Creek 
    Watershed Conservation Dist. of Fountain Inn, 348 S.C. 58, 558 S.E.2d 
    902 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Partition orders, on the other hand, are executed orders 
    because they mandate a one-time change in the ownership of property. As a 
    consequence, Gadsden's motion fails for being wholly outside the scope of 
    Rule 60(b)(5).Â  

 
  AFFIRMED.
  HUFF, BEATTY, JJ., and CURETON, A.J., concur.


 
   
    [1]  At one point Gadsden does offer that the delay was â€œbecause 
    [Appellants] lacked the information necessary to attack the judgment until 
    that time. Once the data were in hand, however, appellants acted promptly 
    to assert their rights.â€Â  (Final Reply Br. of Appellants at 2.)Â  Not only 
    has Gadsden failed to disclose to the Court what this information is that 
    only became available after four years, but also one cannot help but notice 
    that the forgoing sounds suspiciously like a newly discovered evidence argument, 
    which would be time barred under Rule 60(b)(2), SCRCP.Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
S.C. Farm Bureau Mutual Insurance Company, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Mimi K. Oates, as GAL for Jonathan David Oates, 
        Jr., a minor under the age of 14, Mimi K. Oates, individually, Jonathan 
        D. Oates, Sr., individually, James W. Whitmore, Mary D. Whitmore, Dana 
        Tomlin, individually and d/b/a Tender Loving Daycare (TLC) and Angela 
        Dawn Adams, Defendants,
of whom Mimi K. Oates, as GAL for Jonathan 
        David Oates, Jr., Mimi K. Oates, Individually, and Jonathan D. Oates, 
        Sr., Individually are the, Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
J. Buford Grier, Special Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 3692
Submitted September 8, 2003 â€“ Filed 
  November 3, 2003

AFFIRMED 

 

  
    
      
James W. Tucker, Jr., of Rock Hill, for Appellants.
Forrest C. Wilkerson, of Rock Hill, for Respondent.
        
      
    
  

HOWARD, J.:Â  S.C. Farm Bureau Mutual Insurance 
  Company (â€œFarm Bureauâ€) brought this declaratory judgment action seeking a declaration 
  that it did not provide coverage and had no duty to defend a pending tort action 
  brought against its insured, Tender Loving Care Day Care (â€œTLCâ€), and TLCâ€™s 
  owners, Jonathan W. Whitmore, Mary D. Whitmore, and Dana Tomlin.Â  The circuit 
  court ruled the Farm Bureau policy provided no coverage for the underlying claim 
  and Farm Bureau had no duty to defend.Â  We affirm. 
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On May 4, 1997, Farm Bureau issued an insurance 
  policy to TLC, insuring for damages it may become legally liable to pay for 
  bodily injury or property damage arising out of the ownership or maintenance 
  of its premises.Â  The policy, known as a special multi-peril liability policy, 
  named TLC as the insured and provided: 

[Farm Bureau] will pay on behalf of the insured all sums 
  which the insured shall become legally obligated to pay as damages because of 
  bodily injury or property damage to which this insurance applies, caused by 
  an occurrence, and arising out of the ownership, maintenance or use of the insured 
  premises . . . and the company shall have the right and duty to defend any suit 
  against the insured seeking damages on account of such bodily injury or property 
  damage . . . .Â  

The policy also contained endorsement MP0023, entitled â€œAdditional 
  Policy Exclusion Endorsement.â€Â  The exclusion stated:Â  â€œThis insurance does 
  not apply to bodily injury, property damage, or premises medical payments:Â  
  (a) arising out of any acts . . . of sexual or physical molestation, 
  abuse, assault, or harassment caused . . . by any insured, or agent thereof 
  . . . .â€Â  (emphasis added). 
Following the issuance of the policy, Mimi K. Oates 
  and Jonathan D. Oates, Sr. (â€œOatesâ€) brought a tort action on behalf of themselves 
  and their infant son, Jonathan, against TLC, its owners, and its employee, Angela 
  Dawn Adams, alleging Adams severely injured Jonathan while he was in Adamsâ€™ 
  care. According to the complaint, Jonathan suffered permanent injuries from 
  â€œshaken baby syndromeâ€ on May 14, 1997.Â  
Paraphrasing the complaint, it alleges that TLC 
  and the owners of TLC are liable for the injuries to Jonathan caused by Adams 
  because they were negligent in hiring her, training her, supervising her, understaffing 
  the facility, failing to investigate reports of injuries, and generally, by 
  allowing Adams to mistreat and/or injure Jonathan.Â  The complaint also alleges 
  Adams was an employee acting within the scope of her employment at the time 
  of the injury, and was negligent in allowing herself to be placed in a position 
  of caring for more children than her capabilities permitted, in injuring Jonathan 
  on one or more occasions, in failing to ask for assistance, and in treating 
  the child in a manner inconsistent with a nurturing caregiver.Â  
Farm Bureau brought this declaratory judgment action 
  to determine whether its insurance policy provided coverage for the acts forming 
  the basis of the underlying tort claim, thus contractually requiring Farm Bureau 
  to defend the suit.Â  The circuit court ruled the acts alleged in the underlying 
  tort action were not within Farm Bureauâ€™s policy coverage because:Â  1) the policyâ€™s 
  exclusionary clause excluded Oatesâ€™ negligence claims; and 2) Adamsâ€™ acts did 
  not constitute an â€œoccurrenceâ€ within the provisions of the policy.Â  Oates appeals.Â  
  We affirm.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Oates argues the trial court erred by 
  finding Oatesâ€™ negligence claims were excluded by the policyâ€™s exclusionary 
  clause.Â  We disagree.
â€œThe cardinal rule of contract interpretation 
  is to ascertain and give legal effect toâ€ the partiesâ€™ intentions as determined 
  by the contract language.Â  United Dominion Realty Trust, Inc. v. Wal-Mart 
  Stores, Inc., 307 S.C. 102, 105, 413 S.E.2d 866, 868 (Ct. App. 1992); seeÂ  
  Torrington Co. v. Aetna Cas. & Sur. Co., 264 S.C. 636, 643, 216 S.E.2d 
  547, 550 (1975) (holding parties to a contract have the right to construct their 
  own contract without interference from courts to rewrite or torture the meaning 
  of the policy to extend coverage). When a contract is unambiguous a court must 
  construe its provisions according to the terms the parties used, understood 
  in their plain, ordinary, and popular sense.Â  C.A.N. Enter., Inc. v. South 
  Carolina Health and Human Servs.Â  Fin. Commâ€™n, 296 S.C. 373, 377, 373 S.E.2d 
  584, 586 (1988).
The determination of whether an insurance 
  company is obligated to defend an action under its policy provisions is based 
  on the allegations of the complaint.Â  If the facts alleged in the complaint 
  fail to bring the case within the policyâ€™s coverage, the insurer has no obligation 
  to defend.Â  South Carolina Med. Malpractice Liab. Ins. Joint Underwriting 
  Assâ€™n v. Ferry, 291 S.C. 460, 463, 354 S.E.2d 378, 380 (1987).
Oatesâ€™ tort claim alleges the owners were 
  negligent, and as a result, Adams abused Jonathan, causing him bodily injuries.Â  
  Oates does not allege any other damages as a result of the ownersâ€™ negligence. [1] Â Â  Thus, Oatesâ€™ negligence claims are predicated on Jonathanâ€™s 
  injuries, because without Jonathanâ€™s bodily injuries, the separate acts of negligence 
  alleged by Oates are not actionable.Â  See Estate of Cantrell v. Green, 
  302 S.C. 557, 560, 397 S.E.2d 777, 779 (Ct. App. 1990) (holding to prevail in 
  an action founded in negligence, the plaintiff must establish the following 
  three elements:Â  (1) a duty of care owed by the defendant to the plaintiff;Â  
  (2) a breach of that duty by a negligent act or omission; and (3) damage 
  proximately caused by a breach of duty).
Consequently, we must determine if Jonathanâ€™s bodily 
  injuries are excluded by the policy, for if his bodily injuries are excluded 
  by the policy, Oatesâ€™ negligence claims will also be excluded.Â  See McPherson 
  v. Michigan Mut. Ins. Co., 310 S.C. 316, 320, 426 S.E.2d 770, 772 (1993) 
  (holding plaintiffâ€™s tort claims against defendant for negligent training and 
  supervision were excluded by provisions of the insurance contract, where plaintiffâ€™s 
  injuries occurred during a car accident, and the insurance contract excluded 
  coverage for damages â€œarising out ofâ€ the use, operation, or ownership of an 
  automobile); Sphere Drake Ins. Co. v. Litchfield, 313 S.C. 471, 474, 
  438 S.E.2d 275, 277 (Ct. App. 1993) (holding plaintiffâ€™s negligence claims were 
  excluded under the provisions of an insurance policy where the policy excluded 
  any damages â€œarising out ofâ€ assault and battery, and plaintiff only alleged 
  physical damages incurred when employees of the defendant attacked him).Â  
The policy states itÂ  â€œdoes not apply to 
  bodilyÂ  injury . . . (a) arising out of any acts . . . of . . 
  . abuse . . . caused . . . by any insured, or agent thereof . . . .â€Â  
  (emphasis added).Â  (R. 132).Â  We construe the language â€œarising out ofâ€ narrowly 
  to mean â€œcaused by.â€Â  McPherson, 310 S.C. at 320, 426 S.E.2d at 771.
Farm Bureauâ€™s insurance policy does not 
  define â€œabuse.â€Â  Therefore, we look to the common meaning of â€œabuseâ€ in conjunction 
  with the other language of the contract to determine its meaning within the 
  policy.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  See Strother v. Lexington County Recreation Commâ€™n, 
  332 S.C. 54, 62, 504 S.E.2d 117, 122 (1998) (holding when faced with an undefined 
  term, the court must interpret the term in accord with its usual and customary 
  meaning); USAA Property and Casualty Ins. Co. v. Rowland, 312 S.C. 536, 
  539, 435 S.E.2d 879, 881-82 (Ct. App. 1993) (holding when a term is not defined 
  in an insurance policy, the court should define the term according to the usual 
  understanding of the termâ€™s significance to the normal person); see also 
  Heilker v. Zoning Bd. of Appeals for City of Beaufort, 346 S.C. 401, 
  409, 552 S.E.2d 42, 46 (Ct. App. 2001) (holding dictionaries can be helpful 
  tools for the purpose of defining terms);Â  MGC Mgmt. of Charleston v. Kinghorn 
  Ins. Agency, 336 S.C. 542, 549, 520 S.E.2d 820, 823 (Ct. App. 1999) (holding 
  the court must give insurance policy language its plain, ordinary, and popular 
  meaning).Â Â  
 Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary defines 
  â€œabuseâ€ as â€œ[a] depart[ure] from legal or reasonable use in dealing with (a 
  person or thing); toÂ Â Â Â Â Â  misuse . . . . To injure (a person) physically or 
  mentally.â€Â  Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 8 (7th ed. 2000); see also 
  The American Heritage Dictionary of the English Language 6 (1973) (stating 
  abuse means â€œ[t]o hurt or injure by maltreatmentâ€).
Similarly, the South Carolina Criminal Code defines 
  â€œchild abuse or neglectâ€™ . . . [as] an act or omission by any person which causes 
  harm to the childâ€™s physical health or welfare . . . .â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-85 
  (2003); see also S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-490(2)(a) (Supp. 2002) 
  (â€œâ€˜Child abuse or neglectâ€™, or â€˜harmâ€™ occurs when . . . [a person] . . . inflicts 
  or allows to be inflicted upon the child physical or mental injury or engages 
  in acts or omissions which present a substantial risk of physical or mental 
  injury to the child . . . .â€).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â 
When the allegations supporting liability in the 
  underlying negligence action are viewed under any of the above-stated definitions 
  of abuse, Jonathanâ€™s injuries arose out of abuse as that term is used in its 
  plain, ordinary, and popular sense.Â  Thus, the bodily injuries Jonathan sustained, 
  and the resulting damages from those injuries, are excluded by the insurance 
  contract.Â  Consequently, Farm Bureau is not contractually required to defend 
  TLC against Oatesâ€™ negligence claims. 
  [2] Â  See South Carolina Med. Malpractice Liab. Ins. Joint Underwriting 
  Assâ€™n, 291 S.C. at 463, 354 S.E.2d at 380 (holding an insurer has no duty 
  to defend where a partyâ€™s claims fail to bring the case within the policyâ€™s 
  coverage).
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, the decision 
  of the circuit court is
AFFIRMED. 
  [3] 
STILWELL and KITTREDGE, JJ., concurring.  

 
   
    [1]  To the extent Oatesâ€™ complaint alleges damages that are not bodily 
    injury or property damages, Oates has not appealed these issues.Â  Thus, they 
    are deemed abandoned on appeal.Â  See Gold Kist Inc. v. Citizens 
    and Southern Nat. Bank of South Carolina, 286 S.C. 272, 275, 333 S.E.2d 
    67, 70 (Ct. App. 1985) (holding issues not argued on appeal are deemed abandoned).Â  
  

 
   
    [2]  Oates also argues the circuit court erred by holding Oatesâ€™ tort 
    claims did not constitute â€œoccurrences,â€ bringing the claims within the insurance 
    policyâ€™s coverage.Â  In that regard, Oates contends this case is analogous 
    to Manufacturers and Merchants Mut. Ins. Co. v. Harvey, 330 S.C. 152, 
    498 S.E.2d 222 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  However, because we hold the claims are specifically 
    excluded by the policy, we need not address this issue.

 
    
 [3]  Because oral argument 
    would not aid the Court in resolving any issue on appeal, we decide this case 
    without oral argument pursuant to South Carolina Appellate Court Rules, Rule 
    215.

description: The court of appeals affirmed the trial court's denial of The Evening Post's FOIA request for access to 911 tapes regarding a highly publicized case, holding (1) the matter was capable for repetition yet evading review and (2) the information requested was exempt from disclosure under South Carolina Code section 30-4-40(a)(3)(B).
