THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Evening Post Publishing Co., d/b/a The Post and Courier, and Ms. Parthinea 
        Snowden, as Personal Representative of the Estate of Edward Snowden, Deceased,       
Plaintiffs,
Of whom Evening Post Publishing Co., d/b/a The Post and Courier, is       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
City of North Charleston,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Gerald C. Smoak, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  3693
Heard June 12, 2003 â€“ Filed November 17, 2003 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
John J. Kerr, of Charleston, for Appellant.
Derk B. K. Van Raalte, IV and J. Brady Hair, both of North 
  Charleston; and Richard W. Lingenfelter, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

JEFFERSON, Acting J.:Â  The Post and Courier 
  filed a Freedom of Information Act request seeking access to 911 tapes the City 
  of North Charleston had in its possession regarding the shooting death of Eric 
  Snowden.Â  The City refused the request because the tapes were to be used in 
  an upcoming lynching trial.Â  The Post and Courier filed a declaratory judgment 
  action seeking access to the tapes and the trial court denied access, finding 
  the Act exempted the tapes from premature disclosure because they were to be 
  used in a prospective law enforcement action. Â The Post and Courier appeals, 
  and we affirm.
FACTS
On October 21, 2000, four white men attacked 
  a black man, Eric Snowden, in front of a video store in North Charleston.Â  The 
  store owner called 911 and police were dispatched to the video store.Â  When 
  the officers arrived, they found Snowden inside the store, armed with a handgun.Â  
  The officers shot and killed Snowden.Â  The video store owner remained on the 
  phone with the 911 dispatcher throughout the entire incident, and the 911 call 
  was audio taped.Â  The tapes included conversations between the officers and 
  the dispatcher and contained contemporaneous accounts of the events giving rise 
  to the lynching charges.
The four men who attacked Snowden were 
  arrested and charged with lynching.Â  On June 21, 2001, after reviewing the transcript 
  of the 911 call and listening to the taped recording, the solicitor decided 
  not to press charges against the police officers who shot Snowden.Â  On June 
  26, 2001, The Post and Courier filed a Freedom of Information Act request with 
  the City asking for production of the audio taped 911 call.Â  The solicitor informed 
  The Post and Courier that he considered the tapes evidence in the upcoming lynching 
  trial of the four men.Â  The solicitor denied the request to immediately produce 
  the tapes, but offered to give the tapes to The Post and Courier after 
  the trial.Â  Based on the solicitorâ€™s evidentiary assessment and request for 
  a delayed release, the City refused to turn over the tapes, stating they were 
  exempt from production prior to the lynching trial by S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 30-4-40(a)(3)(B) 
  (Supp. 2002) of the Freedom of Information Act. 
The Post and Courier filed a declaratory 
  judgment action seeking the production of the 911 tapes.Â  The estate of Eric 
  Snowden intervened in the case also seeking the production of the tapes in a 
  civil action it filed against the City.Â  The trial court denied The Post 
  and Courierâ€™s request for immediate production of the tapes, but allowed the 
  production of the tapes to Eric Snowdenâ€™s estate. [1] Â  The trial court found the tapes fell under the exemption in 
  section 30-4-40(a)(3)(B) and ruled the City did not have to produce the tapes 
  until after the trial.Â  On February 26, 2002, when the solicitor played the 
  911 tapes in court during the lynching trial, the City released the transcript 
  of the 911 tapes to The Post and Courier.Â  The Post and Courier appeals the 
  denial of its declaratory judgment action.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Mootness
The City argues that The Post and Courierâ€™s 
  appeal is moot since the City released the tapes to The Post and Courier at 
  the conclusion of the lynching trial.Â  We disagree.
A matter becomes moot â€œwhen judgment, 
  if rendered, will have no practical legal effect upon [the] existing controversy.Â  
  This is true when some event occurs making it impossible for [the] reviewing 
  Court to grant effectual relief.â€Â  Curtis v. State, 345 S.C. 557, 567-68, 
  549 S.E.2d 591, 596 (2001) (alteration in original) (quoting Mathis v. South 
  Carolina State Highway Depâ€™t, 260 S.C. 344, 346, 195 S.E.2d 713, 715 (1973)), 
  cert. denied, 535 U.S. 926 (2002). Â In civil cases, there are 
  three exceptions to the mootness doctrine:Â  (1) an appellate court can retain 
  jurisdiction if the issue is capable of repetition yet evading review, (2) an 
  appellate court can decide cases of urgency to establish a rule for future conduct 
  in matters of important public interest, and (3) if the decision by the trial 
  court can affect future events or have collateral consequences to the parties, 
  the appellate court can take jurisdiction.Â  Id. at 568, 549 S.E.2d at 
  596.
In Byrd v. Irmo High School, 321 
  S.C. 426, 468 S.E.2d 861 (1996), a student challenged the school districtâ€™s 
  order which suspended him for ten days for coming onto campus after consuming 
  alcohol.Â  The court chose to hear the case because school suspensions are very 
  brief and are usually completed before judicial review can take place.Â  Id. 
  at 432, 468 S.E.2d at 864.Â  Similarly, although we can grant no further relief 
  in the current appeal, we choose to address The Post and Courierâ€™s argument 
  because the facts presented here are capable of repetition yet evading review.Â  

II.Â  Application of the Statute
The Post and Courier argues the trial 
  court erred when it denied its request to compel the City to turn the tapes 
  over to it pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act.Â  We disagree.Â  
The legislature exempted certain items 
  from disclosure under the Freedom of Information Act as follows:

Records of law enforcement and public safety agencies not 
  otherwise available by state and federal law that were compiled in the process 
  of detecting and investigating crime [are exempt from disclosure under the provisions 
  of the Freedom of Information Act] if the disclosure of the information would 
  harm the agency by:
. . . the premature release of information to be used in 
  a prospective law enforcement action.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 30-4-40(a)(3)(B) (Supp. 2002).
 In Turner v. North Charleston Police 
  Department, 290 S.C. 511, 351 S.E.2d 583 (Ct. App. 1986), a husband 
  and wife were involved in a series of violent altercations culminating in the 
  shooting and serious injury of the wife.Â  The wife claimed she made a series 
  of calls to the police prior to the shooting.Â  The wife made a request for access 
  to the police departmentâ€™s tape recordings, written files, and daily activities 
  sheets.Â  The trial court denied her access to the tape recordings and the written 
  files.Â  The police department informed the city that the husband was about to 
  be indicted and tried in the next few weeks for shooting his wife.Â  The trial 
  court found that the exception exempting disclosure of information to be used 
  in criminal proceedings applied.Â  The wife appealed, and we affirmed the trial 
  courtâ€™s ruling.Â  Id. at 513, 351 S.E.2d at 584.
Additionally, in State v. Robinson, 
  305 S.C. 469, 476-77, 409 S.E.2d 404, 409 (1991), the supreme court held that 
  â€œ[t]he specific exemption under Â§ 30-4-40(a)(3)(B) for â€˜the premature release 
  of information to be used in a prospective law enforcement actionâ€™ clearly 
  exempts information regarding pending criminal prosecutions.Â  No specific 
  showing of harm is required by the State if the request involves such material.â€Â  
  [Emphasis added.]Â  
We find that the facts of this case fall 
  squarely within Turner.Â  The 911 tapes were to be used as evidence in 
  the forthcoming lynching trial and therefore fell within the exception listed 
  in section 30-4-40(a)(3)(B). 
 AFFIRMED.Â Â Â Â Â  
 HOWARD and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

 
   [1] Â  Access to the 911 tapes was to be provided to 
    Eric Snowdenâ€™s Estate upon proper request pursuant to the discovery provisions 
    of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure.Â  The criminal defendants in 
    the lynching trial were provided transcripts of the 911 tapes pursuant to 
    Rule 5 of the South Carolina Rules of Criminal Procedure.Â  The trial court 
    expressly prohibited the attorneys or their clients from disclosing the tapes, 
    copies of the tapes, transcripts, or any other summary or information related 
    thereto, to the media.Â  The court allowed the attorneys to disclose the information 
    to their clients and agents for the limited purposes sanctioned by the applicable 
    Rules of Procedure.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Johnny Crawford and Joan Wilson, Plaintiffs,
Of whom Johnny Crawford is Appellant,
v.
Janice Henderson, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â Gary E. Clary, Circuit Court Judge
Â Donald W. Beatty, Circuit Court Judge
Â John C. Few, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3694
Heard April 9, 2003 â€“ Filed November 
  17, 2003

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Samuel Darryl Harms, of Greenville, for Appellant.
Karl S. Brehmer and J. Austin Hood, both of Columbia, for 
  Respondent.
      
    
  

CONNOR, J.:Â  Johnny Crawford brought suit 
  against Janice Henderson and his underinsured motorist carrier (â€œUIMâ€), Southern 
  Heritage Insurance Company, seeking to recover damages from injuries suffered 
  in an automobile accident.Â  The jury awarded Crawford $1,099.38 in actual damages.Â  
  On appeal, Crawford asserts the circuit court erred in quashing Crawfordâ€™s subpoena 
  to depose Henderson a second time.Â  He contends the UIM carrierâ€™s attorney should 
  not have been able to claim an attorney-client privilege to limit the first 
  deposition based on the following reasons:Â  (1) an attorney-client privilege 
  did not exist between Henderson and the UIM carrierâ€™s attorney; and (2) any 
  alleged attorney-client privilege was waived by counselâ€™s failure to file a 
  motion for a protective order pursuant to Rule 30(j)(3), SCRCP.Â  Finally, Crawford 
  contends the circuit court erred in permitting a nurse practitioner to give 
  an opinion regarding the cause of Crawfordâ€™s injuries.Â  We affirm in part, reverse 
  in part, and remand. 
FACTS
This case arose out of an automobile accident 
  between Janice Henderson and Johnny Crawford.Â  While leaving a gas station, 
  Henderson pulled out into traffic on Highway 290 in Duncan and was struck by 
  Crawford.Â  Henderson testified she did not immediately see Crawfordâ€™s vehicle 
  because a truck that was entering the gas station blocked her line of sight. 

Crawford sued Henderson seeking to recover damages 
  for injuries both he and his passenger, Joan Wilson, suffered in the accident.Â  
  After Crawford and Wilson settled the liability limits of Hendersonâ€™s policy 
  and entered into a covenant not to execute any judgment against Henderson, they 
  sought to recover damages from Southern Heritage Insurance Company (â€œSouthernâ€), 
  the UIM carrier. 
Crawford attempted to take Hendersonâ€™s deposition 
  four times.Â  Each time, Crawford served Southernâ€™s attorney, Karl Brehmer, with 
  the notices of the depositions. Â Henderson failed to appear. Â Ultimately, 
  Crawford filed a motion in circuit court seeking an order to compel Henderson 
  to appear for her deposition or be held in contempt.Â Â  
At the hearing, Brehmer appeared and informed the 
  court that he represented the UIM carrier and had no control over Henderson.Â  
  Counsel claimed he had attempted to find Henderson in order to get her to appear 
  for a deposition. 
After hearing arguments, the circuit court found 
  Brehmer represented Henderson in name only and, therefore, Crawford would have 
  to personally serve Henderson with the notice of deposition.Â  The court reasoned, 
  â€œ[Counsel] does represent [Henderson], . . . for purposes of litigating liability 
  and damages.Â  But for purposes of paying money, . . .Â  itâ€™s very clear that 
  he represents the insurance carrier and he made that clear.â€Â  Â Â 
Crawford served Henderson and she appeared for 
  a deposition on February 21, 2001.Â  During the deposition, Crawfordâ€™s counsel 
  asked Henderson if she had discussed the case with Brehmer prior to the deposition 
  and asked her to relate the substance of the conversations.Â  Brehmer instructed 
  Henderson not to answer the question asserting the answer would violate the 
  attorney-client privilege.Â Â  Henderson did not answer the question and the deposition 
  was concluded. 
Crawford served Henderson with a second subpoena 
  and notice of deposition scheduled for June 19, 2001.Â Â  On June 4, 2001, Brehmer 
  filed a motion for a protective order pursuant to Rules 26(c) and 30(a)(2) of 
  the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure. [1] Â  Counsel contended Crawford had already taken 
  Hendersonâ€™s deposition, the parties had not agreed to multiple depositions, 
  and good cause did not exist to compel an additional deposition.Â  In 
  response, Crawford moved to quash the motion for a protective order on the following 
  grounds:Â  (1) Henderson had not been served with the motion; (2) Brehmer could 
  not assert the attorney-client privilege because he had previously stated he 
  was not Hendersonâ€™s attorney; and (3) even if the attorney-client privilege 
  existed, it was waived because the procedural requirements of Rule 30(j)(3) 
  of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure, which permit a witness not to 
  answer a deposition question, had not been met.
The circuit court granted Brehmerâ€™s motion for 
  a protective order.Â  As a result, Hendersonâ€™s deposition was never reconvened 
  and the case proceeded to trial.Â  The jury returned a verdict in favor of the 
  plaintiffs and awarded $1,099.38 to Crawford and $30,413.61 to Wilson.Â  Crawford 
  appeals. [2] Â Â Â 


 
 
DISCUSSION
I.Â  Existence of Attorney-Client Privilege
Crawford argues the circuit court erred when it 
  granted Brehmerâ€™s motion for a protective order because, as a matter of law, 
  an attorney-client relationship does not exist between a UIM carrierâ€™s attorney 
  and an underinsured motorist, i.e., the named defendant.Â  Even if this 
  relationship can be established, Crawford contends the conversations between 
  Henderson and Brehmer were not protected by the attorney-client privilege. 
A.
Although this case presents several related issues, 
  the threshold matter is to define the relationship created between a UIM carrierâ€™s 
  attorney and the named defendant.Â Â Â  
The attorney-client privilege protects 
  against disclosure of confidential communications by a client to his or her 
  attorney.Â  State v. Owens, 309 S.C. 402, 407, 424 S.E.2d 473, 476 (1992).Â  
  â€œThe privilege is strictly construed to protect only confidences disclosed within 
  the relationship.â€Â  Id. at 407, 424 S.E.2d at 477.Â  To establish an attorney-client 
  privilege, the person asserting the privilege must show that the relationship 
  between the parties was that of attorney and client and that the communications 
  were confidential in nature.Â  Marshall v. Marshall, 282 S.C. 534, 538-39, 
  320 S.E.2d 44, 47 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  In order to obtain the status of a client, 
  the person must communicate in confidence with an attorney for the purpose of 
  obtaining legal advice.Â  Id. at 539, 320 S.E.2d at 47.Â  The advice or 
  assistance must be sought with a view to employing the attorney professionally 
  whether or not actual employment occurs.Â  Id.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â 
Initially, we note there is no contractual 
  relationship between the UIM carrierâ€™s attorney and the named defendant.Â  As 
  conceded by Southern, a contract did not exist between Henderson and Southern.Â  
  Instead, Crawford through his premium payment directly contracted with Southern.
Significantly, our Supreme Court has held 
  the rights of the UIM carrier and the named defendant are not synonymous, and, 
  in fact, may be conflicting.Â  Even though our Supreme Court has not directly 
  addressed the issue in the instant case, we our guided by the analysis in Broome 
  v. Watts, 319 S.C. 337, 461 S.E.2d 46 (1995).Â  In Broome, Carol and 
  John Broome sued Watts for injuries sustained in an automobile accident.Â  Nationwide 
  Mutual Insurance Company (Nationwide) insured Watts for policy limits in the 
  amount of $50,000/$100,000.Â  The Broomes had underinsured motorist coverage 
  with United Services Automobile Association (USAA).Â  As required by section 
  38-77-160 of the South Carolina Code of Laws, the Broomes served USAA with the 
  complaints. [3] Â  USAA filed notices of appearance and motions for intervention 
  in both cases.Â  Shortly thereafter, the Broomes, Watts, and Nationwide entered 
  into a settlement agreement in which Nationwide agreed to pay its $50,000 liability 
  limits to the Broomes.Â  Pursuant to the agreement, Watts waived her right to 
  a jury trial and the Broomes agreed not to execute against Watts or Nationwide 
  any judgment obtained against Watts.Â  The Broomes, however, decided to proceed 
  with an action to determine damages for purposes of UIM coverage.Â  USAA was 
  not a party to the agreement.Â  USAA assumed the defense of the action under 
  section 38-77-160, filed answers, and requested a jury trial.Â  Over the Broomesâ€™ 
  objections, the judge ordered a jury trial.
On appeal, the Broomes asserted USAA was 
  bound by the settlement agreement.Â  Because Watts is the named defendant, the 
  Broomes contended the named defendantâ€™s waiver of a jury trial bound USAA even 
  though it was not a party to the settlement agreement.Â  Our Supreme Court rejected 
  the Broomesâ€™ argument, finding that Watts could not give up USAAâ€™s right to 
  a jury trial.Â  Broome, 319 S.C. at 340, 461 S.E.2d at 48.Â  
Citing section 38-77-160 and a case interpreting 
  this statute, the Court found that a waiver by Watts was not â€œtantamount to 
  a waiver by USAA, because it blurs the distinction between the named defendant 
  (Watts) and the actual defendant (USAA) which must pay damages on behalf of 
  the named defendant in the event of liability.â€Â  Broome, 319 S.C. at 
  340, 461 S.E.2d at 48; see Williams v. Selective Ins. Co. of the Southeast, 
  315 S.C. 532, 534-35, 446 S.E.2d 402, 404 (1994) (holding that a UIM carrier 
  is entitled to assume control of the defense on an action even if the insured 
  chooses to settle with the at-fault driverâ€™s liability carrier).Â Â  The Court 
  concluded, â€œ[a]lthough the UIM carrier â€˜steps into the shoesâ€™ of the underinsured 
  motorist, it has rights separate and distinct from those of the underinsured 
  motorist.â€Â  Broome, 319 S.C. at 340, 461 S.E.2d at 48; see also 
  Ex parte Allstate Ins. Co., 339 S.C. 202, 528 S.E.2d 679 (Ct. App. 2000) 
  (holding in action to recover underinsured motorist benefits, the plaintiff 
  was required to serve UIM carrier with action against underinsured motorist 
  prior to trial; recognizing UIM carrier had rights that were separate and distinct 
  from the underinsured motorist and was not in privity with underinsured motorist 
  or his liability carrier).
Despite the Supreme Courtâ€™s discussions 
  in Broome, Southern [4]  
  contends section 38-77-160 supports a â€œquasi attorney-clientâ€ relationship.Â  
  Specifically, Southern claims the UIM carrierâ€™s attorney essentially becomes 
  the attorney for the named defendant because he has stepped into the shoes of 
  the defendantâ€™s original attorney who was retained by the liability insurance 
  carrier.Â  We disagree for several reasons.Â  First, Southern has not cited nor 
  have we found any authority that South Carolina recognizes a â€œquasi attorney-client 
  relationship.â€Â  Secondly, and most significantly, the Supreme Court established 
  in Broome and Williams that the interests of a UIM carrier and 
  a named defendant are separate and distinct.Â Â  Clearly, once the named defendant 
  has settled for his liability policy limits, he no longer has a stake in the 
  outcome of the litigation.Â  The UIM carrier, on the other hand, still has a 
  viable, financial interest in the case.Â  As a result, the attorney for the UIM 
  carrier represents the carrier and not the named defendant.Â  Even though the 
  UIM carrier â€œsteps into the shoesâ€ of the named defendant, the procedure is 
  not in totality but merely to the point of coverage.Â  Thus, there is no direct 
  relationship between the UIM carrierâ€™s attorney and the named defendant.
In addition to the lack of case law and 
  statutory support for the creation of an attorney-client relationship in this 
  situation, we find there are ethical considerations that would also prohibit 
  it.Â  These issues may be illustrated by comparing an established attorney-client 
  relationship with the facts of the instant case.Â  
First, if a relationship exists, the attorney has 
  some degree of control over the client and the client, in turn, has some input 
  in the outcome of the litigation.Â  See Rule 1.2(a), RPC, Rule 407, SCACR 
  (â€œA lawyer shall abide by a clientâ€™s decisions concerning the objectives of 
  representation . . . and shall consult with the client as to the means by which 
  they are to be pursued.Â  A lawyer shall abide by a clientâ€™s decision whether 
  to accept an offer of settlement of a matter.â€).Â  Here, the UIM carrierâ€™s attorney 
  has no control over the named defendant because the attorney represents the 
  insurance company and the named defendant no longer has an interest once a covenant 
  not to execute is entered into with the defendantâ€™s liability carrier.Â  
Secondly, under the normal situation, a plaintiffâ€™s 
  attorney is not permitted to have direct contact with the defendant, but instead, 
  must serve all pleadings and motions upon the defendantâ€™s attorney.Â  See 
  Rule 4.2, RPC, Rule 407, SCACR (â€œIn representing a client, a lawyer shall not 
  communicate about the subject of the representation with a party the lawyer 
  knows to be represented by another lawyer in the matter, unless the lawyer has 
  the consent of the other lawyer or is authorized by law to do so.â€).Â  In the 
  case at bar, the named defendant and the UIM carrier must both be served with 
  the pleadings.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-77-160 (2002) (â€œNo action may 
  be brought under the underinsured motorist provision unless copies of the pleadings 
  in the action establishing liability are served in the manner provided by law 
  upon the insurer writing the underinsured motorist provision.â€); Louden v. 
  Moragne, 327 S.C. 465, 486 S.E.2d 525 (Ct. App. 1997) (holding named defendant 
  in an action for benefits under a plaintiffâ€™s underinsured motorist policy must 
  be properly served with summons and complaint).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Moreover, if an attorney-client relationship were 
  permitted in this instance, there exists a problem with dual representation.Â  
  Specifically, the question becomes whether the UIM carrierâ€™s attorney can simultaneously 
  represent the insurance company and a named defendant who has no direct relationship 
  with the UIM carrier and whose interests are separate and distinct.Â  See 
  McNair v. Rainsford, 330 S.C. 332, 344, 499 S.E.2d 488, 494 (Ct. App. 
  1998) (â€œAn attorney who represents more than one client must be cognizant of 
  the vicissitudes of dual representation.Â  Dual representation is not per 
  se unethical, but raises a spectre of a violation of Rules 1.7 and 2.2 of 
  the South Carolina Rules of Professional Conduct (RPC), Rule 407, SCACR.â€); 
  see Rule 1.7, RPC, Rule 407, SCACR (outlining rules prohibiting attorney 
  from representing client where there exists a conflict of interest).Â  
B.
Assuming arguendo that an attorney-client 
  relationship can be created between a UIM carrierâ€™s attorney and the named defendant, 
  Crawford asserts the attorney-client privilege could not be asserted under the 
  facts of this case. 
Brehmer specifically disclaimed the existence of 
  an attorney-client relationship.Â  He maintained Southern retained him to represent 
  its interest pursuant to section 38-77-160.Â Â  He also stated he had no right 
  to control Henderson.Â Â  Furthermore, other than Brehmerâ€™s appearance at Hendersonâ€™s 
  deposition and his claim that he conferred with Henderson prior to the deposition, 
  there is no evidence that Brehmer acted as Hendersonâ€™s legal advisor.Â  From 
  all indications, it seems that Brehmer appeared at the deposition in order to 
  represent Southernâ€™s interests.Â  Based on our review of the record, Brehmer 
  has not demonstrated that Henderson was his client.Â  See State v. 
  Love, 275 S.C. 55, 59, 271 S.E.2d 110, 112 (1980) (stating burden of establishing 
  attorney-client privilege is upon the person asserting it).Â  Even viewing the 
  situation from Hendersonâ€™s perspective, as Brehmer urges this Court to do, we 
  find no evidence that she had a reasonable belief or expectation that Brehmer 
  directly represented her. 
Based on the foregoing, we hold the circuit 
  court erred in quashing Crawfordâ€™s subpoena to reconvene Hendersonâ€™s deposition.Â  
  Because any communications between Brehmer and Henderson were not protected 
  by the attorney-client privilege, Crawford should have been permitted to question 
  her in this regard.Â  Accordingly, we remand for Crawford to take Hendersonâ€™s 
  deposition and, as a result, remand for a new trial.
C.
Given our conclusion, we are cognizant 
  of the policy concerns presented by Southern.Â  Specifically, Southern asserts 
  an attorney-client privilege should necessarily be created because there must 
  be some level of confidentiality between an attorney for a UIM carrier and the 
  named defendant.Â  Without this protection, Southern claims a UIM carrierâ€™s attorneyâ€™s 
  ability to defend the case will be adversely affected.
As previously discussed, case law, statutes, 
  and ethical rules compel our holding that an attorney-client relationship is 
  not established between a UIM carrierâ€™s attorney and a named defendant.Â  Moreover, 
  to hold otherwise would effectively limit the benefits a plaintiff receives 
  from purchasing UIM coverage.
To avoid the predicament alleged by Southern, 
  it is incumbent upon a UIM carrierâ€™s attorney to inform the named defendant 
  of the parameters of his or her representation.Â  Specifically, the attorney 
  should emphasize that he or she directly represents the carrier and treat the 
  named defendant essentially as a witness.Â  We note that this procedure does 
  not leave the named defendant without direct representation. Contractually, 
  the named defendantâ€™s liability carrier remains obligated to the insured even 
  after the liability limits have been paid.Â  See Cobb v. Benjamin, 
  325 S.C. 573, 584, 482 S.E.2d 589, 594 (Ct. App. 1997) (finding the language 
  of section 38-77-160 â€œgiving the UIM carrier the right to assume control of 
  the defense for its own benefit is . . . consistent with the recognition that 
  the liability carrier who has paid its limits no longer has the same stake in 
  the outcome, even though the contractual obligation to its insured to defend 
  is ongoingâ€).
II.Â  Waiver of Attorney-Client Privilege
Even assuming that Brehmer could assert 
  the attorney-client privilege, Crawford argues it was waived because he failed 
  to comply with the procedural requirements of Rule 30(j) of the South Carolina 
  Rules of Civil Procedure. [5] 
Rule 30(j), which governs the conduct 
  of counsel during depositions, provides in relevant part:

Counsel shall not direct or request that a witness not answer 
  a question, unless that counsel has objected to the question on the ground that 
  the answer is protected by a privilege or a limitation on evidence directed 
  by the court or unless that counsel intends to present a motion under Rule 30(d), 
  SCRCP. In addition, counsel shall have an affirmative duty to inform a witness 
  that, unless such an objection is made, the question must be answered. Counsel 
  directing that a witness not answer a question on those grounds or allowing 
  a witness to refuse to answer a question on those grounds shall 
  move the court for a protective order under Rule 26(c), SCRCP, or 30(d), SCRCP, 
  within five business days of the suspension or termination of the deposition. 
  Failure to timely file such a motion will constitute waiver of the objection, 
  and the deposition may be reconvened.

Rule 30(j)(3), SCRCP (emphasis added). 
Neither Brehmer nor Henderson filed a 
  motion for a protective order within five business days of the termination of 
  the deposition.Â  Because the language of Rule 30(j)(3) is mandatory, any assertion 
  of the attorney-client privilege during the deposition was waived.Â  See 
  Collins v. Doe, 352 S.C. 462, 470, 574 S.E.2d 739, 743 (2002) (â€œUnder 
  the rules of statutory interpretation, use of words such as â€˜shallâ€™ or â€˜mustâ€™ 
  indicates the legislatureâ€™s intent to enact a mandatory requirement.â€).Â Â Â Â  

Despite the requirements 
  of Rule 30(j)(3), Brehmer argues and the circuit court agreed that Crawford 
  failed to sustain his burden to obtain a second deposition under Rule 30(a)(2), 
  which provides in relevant part, â€œThe deposition of any party or witness may 
  only be taken one time in any case except by agreement of the parties through 
  their counsel or by order of the court for good cause shown.â€Â  Rule 30(a)(2), 
  SCRCP.Â Â  Additionally, Brehmer contends Rules 30(a)(2) and 30(j)(3) are in conflict, 
  thus, Crawford still needed to comply with the requirements of Rule 30(a)(2).
However, according to the language of Rule 30(j)(3), 
  Crawford was not required to subpoena the court for a second deposition but 
  was instead permitted to reconvene the first deposition.Â  Given the language 
  of Rule 30(j)(3) allows for the reconvening of the first deposition, it does 
  not conflict with the rules governing the procedure to obtain a second deposition 
  as specified under Rule 30(a)(2).
Finally, Brehmer asserts Hendersonâ€™s deposition 
  should not be reconvened because Crawford allowed the first deposition to proceed 
  after the objection and did not call the trial judge to obtain an immediate 
  ruling.Â  Crawford, however, was not required to do so.Â  Rule 30(j)(3) requires 
  the party asserting the privilege to file the motion for a protective order 
  within five business days of either the suspension or termination of the deposition.Â  
  The language of Rule 30(j)(3) specifying termination of the proceedings permits 
  the deposition to be concluded after its normal course.Â  Therefore, we find 
  the circuit court erred when it denied Crawford the right to reconvene Hendersonâ€™s 
  deposition.Â  Accordingly, we remand the case for a new trial after the conclusion 
  of the deposition.
III.Â  Expert Witness Testimony of Nurse Practitioner
Crawford argues the circuit court erred 
  when it permitted a nurse practitioner who treated Crawford to testify regarding 
  causation given Southern failed to establish the nurse was an expert for purposes 
  of rendering medical diagnoses. [6] 
  Â  
At trial, the parties disputed whether Crawfordâ€™s 
  injuries were caused by the accident or if the injuries were pre-existing from 
  an accident Crawford suffered at work.Â  Crawford testified his right shoulder 
  began to hurt approximately fifteen to twenty minutes after the accident on 
  April 3, 1998.Â  That night, Crawford went to the emergency room where he was 
  given a prescription for pain medication and a muscle relaxant.Â  Nine days later, 
  Crawford sought treatment for his shoulder at an urgent care center.Â  A few 
  days later, Crawford went to an orthopedic specialist, Dr. Postma.Â Â  Dr. Postma 
  prescribed physical therapy for Crawfordâ€™s shoulder. Â Shortly after his 
  last physical therapy appointment, Dr. Postma performed a shoulder manipulation 
  while Crawford was under anesthesia.Â  After the procedure, Crawford went to 
  a pain management center where Dr. Haasis gave Crawford cortisone shots.Â  In 
  his deposition, Dr. Haasis testified he believed Crawfordâ€™s injuries were secondary 
  to the automobile accident.Â  Crawford submitted medical bills in the 
  amount of $25,849.21.
During his testimony, Crawford relayed that on 
  March 17, 1998, he was injured at work when his shirt got caught in a â€œmixer 
  machine.â€Â  As a result of the work-related accident, Crawford sustained injuries 
  that included abrasion burns on his right arm. Â He testified he planned 
  to return to work on Monday when the accident happened on the previous Friday.
In contrast, Henderson testified Crawford did not 
  show any signs of injuries.Â  She stated Crawford was upset and moving around 
  after the accident.
Southern presented the testimony of Victoria Smith, 
  a family nurse practitioner who treated Crawford.Â  Smith testified she saw Crawford 
  on July 29, 1997.Â  On that day, Crawford complained of pain in his right shoulder. 
  When questioned about the results of her physical examination of Crawford, Smith 
  opined that Crawford suffered from bursitis in his right shoulder.Â  Based 
  on this assessment, Smith prescribed medication and physical therapy.
On April 6, 1998, three days after the automobile 
  accident, Smith again saw Crawford.Â  On that day, Crawford complained of pain 
  in his right shoulder and upper arm.Â  Smith testified Crawford also told her 
  about the injuries he had sustained in the work-related accident.Â  Counsel 
  then asked Smith whether Crawford was suffering from bursitis that day.Â  Crawfordâ€™s 
  counsel objected to the question on the grounds that Smith was not a medical 
  doctor and, therefore, was not qualified to give a medical diagnosis.Â  The 
  judge overruled the objection.Â  Smith testified Crawford was not suffering from 
  bursitis, thus, implying Crawford was still experiencing the effects of the 
  work-related injury on that day. 
â€œFor a court to find a witness competent 
  to testify as an expert, the witness must be better qualified than the jury 
  to form an opinion on the particular subject of the testimony.â€Â  Mizzell 
  v. Glover, 351 S.C. 392, 406, 570 S.E.2d 176, 183 (2002); see Rule 
  702, SCRE (â€œIf scientific, technical, or other specialized knowledge will assist 
  the trier of fact to understand the evidence or to determine a fact in issue, 
  a witness qualified as an expert by knowledge, skill, experience, training, 
  or education, may testify thereto in the form of an opinion or otherwise.â€).Â  

Whether to qualify a witness as an expert and admit 
  the expertâ€™s testimony is left to the discretion of the trial court and will 
  not be overturned absent an abuse of that discretion.Â  Payton v. Kearse, 
  329 S.C. 51, 60-61, 495 S.E.2d 205, 211 (1998).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs 
  when the trial court commits an error of law or makes a factual conclusion without 
  evidentiary support.Â  Lee v. Suess, 318 S.C. 283, 285, 457 S.E.2d 344, 
  345 (1995).
In support of his argument, Crawford cites 
  a case in which this Court held a physical therapist was not qualified to testify 
  regarding causation of the plaintiffâ€™s injuries.Â  Nelson v. Taylor, 347 
  S.C. 210, 553 S.E.2d 488 (Ct. App. 2001).Â Â  Based on Nelson, Crawford 
  argues that nurse practitioners are also not statutorily authorized to make 
  medical diagnoses and should not be qualified as experts regarding medical diagnoses.
In Nelson, Pamela Nelson 
  (Nelson) and her husband brought a negligence action against Taylor for personal 
  injuries resulting from an automobile accident.Â  As a result of the accident, 
  Nelson complained of pain in her back, neck, head, and shoulder.Â  Nelson was 
  treated by her family physician, an orthopedic surgeon, a neurosurgeon, a shoulder 
  specialist, a chiropractor, and a physical therapist.Â  At trial, contradicting 
  theories emerged concerning the cause of Nelsonâ€™s injuries.Â  The physical therapist 
  concluded that Nelsonâ€™s injuries stemmed from her use of a mouse at her computer 
  workstation, resulting in rotator cuff tendonitis.Â  The shoulder specialist 
  disagreed finding Nelsonâ€™s injuries were caused by the automobile accident.Â  
  He also ruled out rotator cuff tendonitis.Â  In a deposition, the orthopedic 
  surgeon found no evidence of shoulder impingement. Â The jury awarded Nelson 
  significantly less than what she offered as her medical expenses.Â  
On appeal, Nelson argued the trial judge 
  erred in admitting the physical therapistâ€™s deposition concerning the medical 
  cause of her injuries.Â  Nelson, 347 S.C. at 213, 553 S.E.2d at 489.Â  
  During the physical therapistâ€™s deposition, Nelson had objected to the physical 
  therapistâ€™s diagnosis of her injuries because he was not a medical doctor and 
  had not reviewed Nelsonâ€™s medical records or diagnostic test results.Â  This 
  Court reversed the judgeâ€™s decision to admit the testimony.Â  Id. at 216-17, 
  553 S.E.2d at 491.Â  In reaching this conclusion, we reviewed the statutory scheme 
  created by the General Assembly to define and regulate the practice of physical 
  therapy.Â  Based on the controlling statutes, we determined that a physical therapist 
  is limited in terms of methods of treatment and is not authorized to practice 
  medicine, prescribe medications, or order medical laboratory tests.Â  Id. 
  at 215-16, 553 S.E.2d at 490-91.Â  In view of these statutory restrictions, we 
  held the physical therapist was not qualified to testify regarding causation.Â  
  Id. at 216-17, 553 S.E.2d at 491.Â Â Â Â  
 Nelson is distinguishable from 
  the instant case.Â  First, as will be discussed, the statutory and regulatory 
  provisions governing the practice of nursing are significantly different from 
  those defining the parameters of physical therapy.Â  Secondly, the statute that 
  prohibits a physical therapist from practicing medicine specifically excludes 
  nurse practitioners from this limitation.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 40-45-310 
  (2001) (â€œNothing in this chapter shall be construed to restrict, inhibit, or 
  limit the practice of licensed nurse practitioners . . ..â€).
Although the holding in Nelson 
  is not dispositive, it is, nevertheless, instructive for our analysis of the 
  issue presented in the instant case.Â  As in Nelson, we must review the 
  General Assemblyâ€™s statutory scheme regulating nurse practitioners.
Section 40-33-10 defines several aspects 
  of nursing.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 40-33-10 (2001 & Supp. 2002).Â  Relevant to 
  this case are subsections (f) and (g), which define the practice of nursing 
  and the practice of professional nursing.Â Â  As provided in these subsections, 
  the process of nursing includes direct care and treatment services, which includes 
  the implementation of a physician-prescribed regimen as well as the assessment 
  and nursing diagnosis of health problems.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 40-33-10(f), (g) 
  (2001).Â  In addition to these responsibilities, a professional nurse â€œmay perform 
  additional acts in the extended role requiring special education and training 
  which are agreed to jointly by both the Board of Nursing and the Board of Medical 
  Examiners.Â  Those additional acts agreed to by both boards must be promulgated 
  by the Board of Nursing in its regulations.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 40-33-10 (g) 
  (2001). [7] 
Turning to the specifics of this case, 
  the role of a nurse practitioner is described in the regulations governing the 
  practice of nursing as follows:

â€œNurse Practitionerâ€ means a registered nurse who has completed 
  a post-basic or advanced formal education program acceptable to the Board, and 
  who demonstrates advanced knowledge and skill in assessment and management of 
  physical and psychosocial health-illness status of individuals, and/or families, 
  and/or groups. Nurse practitioners who manage delegated medical aspects of care 
  must have a supervising physician and operate within the â€œapproved written protocols.â€ 


26 S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 91-2(d ) (Supp. 2002); see 
  26 S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 91-6(h)(1) (Supp. 2002) (â€œA Nurse Practitioner or Clinical 
  Nurse Specialist practicing in an extended role shall perform delegated medical 
  acts pursuant to an approved written protocol between the nurse and the physician.â€).
The regulations define the terms â€œdelegated 
  medical actsâ€ and â€œapproved written protocols.â€Â  â€œâ€˜Delegated Medical Actsâ€™ means 
  those additional acts delegated by the physician that include formulating a 
  medical diagnosis and initiating, continuing, and modifying therapies, 
  including prescribing drug therapy, under approved written protocols.â€Â  26 S.C. 
  Code Ann. Regs. 91-1(c) (Supp. 2002) (emphasis added); see 26 S.C. Code 
  Ann. Regs. 91-6(h)(2)(b) (Supp. 2002) (outlining at minimum information that 
  should be included as â€œdelegated medical actsâ€).Â  â€œâ€˜Approved Written Protocolsâ€™ 
  means specific statements developed collaboratively by the physician or the 
  medical staff and the nurse that establish physician delegation for medical 
  aspects of care, including the prescription of medications.â€Â  26 S.C. Code Ann. 
  Regs. 91-2(g) (Supp. 2002).
Reading these statutory provisions and 
  regulations together, we find the General Assembly has authorized a nurse practitioner 
  to diagnose and treat medical conditions if a supervising physician has delegated 
  those acts pursuant to an approved written protocol.Â  Significantly, these provisions 
  expand the role of a nurse practitioner to provide a medical diagnosis in addition 
  to a nursing diagnosis.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 40-33-10(n) (2001) (defining 
  â€œnursing diagnosisâ€ as â€œa clinical judgment about an individual, family, or 
  community which is derived through a nursing assessmentâ€); Flanagan v. Labe, 
  690 A.2d 183 (Pa. 1997) (recognizing distinction between a nursing diagnosis 
  and medical diagnosis); Id. at 186 (â€œ[A] nursing diagnosis identifies 
  signs and symptoms to the extent necessary to carry out the nursing regime.Â  
  It does not, however, make final conclusions about the identity and cause of 
  the underlying disease.â€); cf. Newbern v. State, No. 02-C-01-9106-CR00143, 
  1992 WL 124459 at *3 (Tenn. Crim. App. June 10, 1992) (holding a nurse practitioner 
  could testify as expert in rape trial given â€œa nurse practitioner, unlike the 
  average nurse, can make diagnoses like a doctor and can prescribe non-narcotic 
  medicationâ€).Â  
Turning to the instant case, we must examine the 
  record to see if there is any evidence supporting Smithâ€™s ability to conduct 
  medical diagnoses of patients.Â  Southernâ€™s attorney asked Smith to describe 
  the duties of a nurse practitioner.Â  She responded:

Nurse practitioners are performing delegated medical acts, 
  and that is a collaborative agreement between the physician and the nurse practitioner 
  as to what she can perform, what she feels comfortable in doing, what sheâ€™s 
  been educated to do, and what [the physician] feels comfortable delegating to 
  her.Â  So, it varies from one practice to another what services nurse practitioners 
  performs [sic].Â  

In addition to this testimony, we note 
  Smith had diagnosed Crawford prior to the accident as having bursitis in his 
  shoulder.Â  She treated him and prescribed medication and physical therapy.Â  
  From this testimony, the judge could reasonably infer that a physician had delegated 
  to Smith the power to diagnose.Â  
Crawford, however, asserts that because the requisite 
  â€œwritten protocolâ€ was not offered into evidence by Southern it was error to 
  permit Smith to testify regarding causation.Â  We find this argument is not preserved 
  for our review.Â  First, it was not presented to the trial judge when Crawford 
  objected to Smithâ€™s testimony.Â  Â See Wilder Corp. v. 
  Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic that 
  an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised 
  to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€); 
  see also State v. Bailey, 298 S.C. 1, 5-6, 377 S.E.2d 581, 584 
  (1989) (stating a party may not argue one ground at trial and then an alternative 
  ground on appeal).Â  Secondly, Crawford raised this specific argument for the 
  first time in his reply brief.Â Â  See Glasscock, Inc. v. United States 
  Fidelity & Guar. Co., 348 S.C. 76, 81, 557 S.E.2d 689, 692 (Ct. App. 
  2001), cert. denied (July 10, 2002) (finding that appellant could not 
  raise additional arguments in reply brief because it was not addressed in initial 
  brief); Lister v. NationsBank, 329 S.C. 133, 153, 494 S.E.2d 449, 460 
  (Ct. App. 1997) (stating a point raised for the first time in a reply brief 
  will not be considered by appellate court).Â  Accordingly, we find the judge 
  did not abuse his discretion in permitting Smith to testify regarding her diagnosis 
  of Crawfordâ€™s injury.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
In the future, we believe the party presenting 
  a nurse practitioner as a witness should offer a copy of the â€œapproved written 
  protocolâ€ into evidence in order to clarify the exact medical acts the physician 
  delegated to the nurse practitioner.
CONCLUSION
An attorney-client relationship is not 
  created between a UIM carrierâ€™s attorney and the named defendant.Â  In the absence 
  of this relationship, a UIM carrierâ€™s attorney may not assert the attorney-client 
  privilege to protect communications between he and the named insured.Â  Even 
  if an attorney-client privilege could be asserted, this privilege may be waived 
  if the attorney fails to file for a motion for a protective order pursuant to 
  Rule 30(j)(3) of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure.Â  Finally, a nurse 
  practitioner may testify regarding causation if a physician has delegated the 
  requisite medical acts to the nurse practitioner in â€œapproved written protocol.â€Â  

Accordingly, we reverse the courtâ€™s decision 
  quashing Crawfordâ€™s motion to reconvene Hendersonâ€™s deposition and remand the 
  case for a new trial.Â  We affirm the decision of the court permitting the nurse 
  practitioner to testify regarding the cause of Crawfordâ€™s injuries.
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART AND REMANDED.
ANDERSON and HUFF, JJ., concur.

 
   [1] Â Â  Rule 26(c) of the South Carolina Rules of Civil 
    Procedure provides in pertinent part:Â  
  
  Upon motion by a party 
    or by the person from whom discovery is sought, and for good cause shown, 
    the court in which the action is pending or alternatively, on matters relating 
    to a deposition, the court in the circuit where the deposition is to be taken 
    may make any order which justice requires to protect a party or person from 
    annoyance, embarrassment, oppression, or undue burden by expense, including 
    one or more of the following:Â  (1) that the discovery not be had;Â  (2) that 
    the discovery may be had only on specified terms and conditions, including 
    a designation of the time or place; (3) that the discovery may be had only 
    by a method of discovery other than selected by the party seeking discovery;Â  
    (4) that certain matters not be inquired into or that the scope of the discovery 
    be limited to certain matters; (5) that discovery be conducted with no one 
    present except persons designated by the court . . .. 
  
  Rule 26(c), SCRCP.
  Rule 30(a)(2) states in 
    relevant part, â€œThe deposition of any party or witness may only be taken one 
    time in any case except by agreement of the parties through their counsel 
    or by order of the court for good cause shown.â€ Rule 30(a)(2), SCRCP.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 

 
   [2] Â Â  Wilson is not a party to this appeal.

 
   [3] Â  Section 38-77-160 provides in pertinent part:
  
  No action may be brought under the underinsured motorist 
    provision unless copies of the pleadings in the action establishing liability 
    are served in the manner provided by law upon the insurer writing the underinsured 
    motorist provision.Â  The insurer has the right to appear and defend in the 
    name of the underinsured motorist in any action which may affect its liability 
    and has thirty days after service of process on it in which to appear.Â  The 
    evidence of service upon the insurer may not be made a part of the record.Â  
    In the event the automobile insurance insurer for the putative at-fault insured 
    chooses to settle in part the claims against its insured by payment of its 
    applicable liability limits on behalf of its insured, the underinsured motorist 
    insurer may assume control of the defense of action for its own benefit.Â  
    No underinsured motorist policy may contain a clause requiring the insurerâ€™s 
    consent to settlement with the at-fault party.
  
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-77-160 (2002).Â  Because there 
    have been no substantive amendments made to this statute since the Broome 
    decision, we cite to the most current version of the statute.

 
   
    [4]  We note that although Henderson is the named Respondent, the Respondentâ€™s 
    brief was filed on behalf of Southernâ€™s interests.Â  Therefore, we refer to 
    Southern and Brehmer, Southernâ€™s attorney, throughout our discussion.

 
   
    [5] Â Â  In light of our holding that an attorney-client relationship is 
    not created, we need not address this argument.Â  However, because Rule 30(j) 
    is relatively new with limited application, we decide to analyze this issue.Â  
    Moreover, it provides additional support for our conclusion that the circuit 
    court erred in denying Crawfordâ€™s right to thoroughly depose Henderson.

 
   
    [6] Â  Based on our decision to reconvene Hendersonâ€™s deposition, which 
    will inevitably precipitate a new trial, we need not address Crawfordâ€™s remaining 
    issue.Â  However, because this issue may arise during a second trial, we decide 
    it for the benefit of the parties.

 
   [7] Â Â  Subsection (f) provides:
  
  â€œPractice of nursingâ€ means 
    the provision of services for compensation that assist individuals and groups 
    to obtain or maintain optimal health.Â  Nursing practice is commensurate with 
    the educational preparation and demonstrated competencies of the individual 
    who is accountable to the public for the quality of nursing care.Â  Nursing 
    practice includes the provision of direct care and treatment services including 
    the implementation of a medical regimen as authorized and prescribed by a 
    licensed physician, dentist, or other person authorized by law, teaching, 
    counseling, administration, research, consultation, supervision, delegation, 
    and evaluation of practice.Â  Nursing process includes the assessment and nursing 
    diagnosis of human responses to actual or potential health problems and the 
    planning, intervention, and evaluation of care in the promotion and maintenance 
    of health, the casefinding and nursing management of illness, injury, or infirmity, 
    the restoration of optimum function, or the achievement of a dignified death. 
  
  
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 40-33-10(f) (2001).
  Â Â Â  Subsection (g) provides:
  
  â€œPractice of professional 
    nursingâ€ means the performance for compensation of any acts in the health 
    care process involving the process of assessment, intervention, and evaluation.Â  
    This process includes observation, care, and counsel of the ill, injured, 
    infirm, the promotion and maintenance of health, the administration of medications, 
    and treatments as authorized and prescribed by a licensed physician or a licensed 
    dentist.Â  The application of the nursing process requires substantial specialized 
    independent judgment and skill and is based on knowledge and application of 
    the principles of biophysical and social sciences.Â  The practice of professional 
    nursing includes the teaching and administration, supervision, delegation, 
    and evaluation of nursing practice.Â  A professional nurse may perform additional 
    acts in the extended role requiring special education and training which are 
    agreed to jointly by both the Board of Nursing and the Board of Medical Examiners.Â  
    Those additional acts agreed to by both boards must be promulgated by the 
    Board of Nursing in its regulations.
  
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 40-33-10 
    (g) (2001).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Stephen Hutto, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Clarendon County
Â Thomas W. Cooper, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 3695
Submitted October 10, 2003 â€“ Filed November 
  17, 2003

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Daniel W. Luginbill, of Bamberg, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, and Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, 
  all of Columbia; and Solicitor Cecil Kelley Jackson, of Sumter, for Respondent.
      
    
  

STILWELL, J.:Â  Stephen Hutto appeals the 
  trial courtâ€™s denial of his motion to reconsider sentencing.Â  We affirm. [1] 
FACTS
Hutto and another juvenile escaped from the Department 
  of Juvenile Justiceâ€™s Rimini Marine Institute, killing a supervisor on their 
  work detail in the process.Â  The pair then continued on a crime spree spanning 
  multiple counties.Â  Hutto entered into a plea agreement with the State, agreeing 
  to plead guilty on numerous charges including murder.Â  The agreement provided 
  Hutto would receive maximum concurrent sentences on all charges except the murder 
  charge, with sentencing on that charge left to the trial courtâ€™s sound discretion.
This arrangement allowed the defense to argue Hutto should receive thirty 
  years for murder and for the State to argue he should receive life without parole. 

The court accepted Huttoâ€™s pleas and postponed 
  sentencing for thirty days to allow the defense time to prepare arguments regarding 
  mitigation.Â  When the court reconvened for sentencing it heard arguments and 
  testimony from each side.Â  The State submitted a statement from a jailhouse 
  informant who advised police that Hutto admitted after the crimes that he planned 
  the killing and escape two days before the plan was carried out.Â  The informantâ€™s 
  statement also described details of the murder.Â  
The State also relayed interviews with two juveniles 
  who were housed at Rimini with Hutto.Â  The first discussed seeing Hutto and 
  his co-defendant view a map and hearing them discuss locations in Bamberg and 
  Greenville.Â  This juvenile alleged Huttoâ€™s co-defendant challenged Hutto by 
  taunting, â€œI donâ€™t believe you got the guts to do it.â€Â  
The second juvenile corroborated the first juvenileâ€™s 
  statement regarding the map.Â  The second juvenile also stated Hutto and his 
  co-defendant had told the victim they could kill him, steal his truck, and escape 
  the Institute.Â  Huttoâ€™s co-defendant also testified concerning the crimes. 
At the conclusion of the hearing the court sentenced 
  Hutto to life without parole for murder.Â  Pursuant to his plea agreement, Hutto 
  received maximum concurrent sentences on the other charges.Â  
DISCUSSION
I.Â  Solicitorâ€™s Comment
Hutto asserts that prior to the beginning of the 
  sentencing hearing one of the solicitors approached the van where Hutto was 
  awaiting transport into the courtroom and told the guards, â€œdonâ€™t be in a hurry 
  because itâ€™s a sure thing he will be going back with you with a life sentence.â€Â  
  Hutto asserts the statement deprived him of due process by intimidating him 
  from assisting in his own defense. 
Traditionally the relevant question to ask in â€œsolicitor 
  commentâ€ cases is whether the comments so infected the trial with unfairness 
  as to make the resulting conviction a denial of due process.Â  Donnelly v. 
  DeChristoforo, 416 U.S. 637 (1974).Â  We have been unable to find another 
  court that has found a denial of due process where the solicitorâ€™s comments 
  were uttered to third parties who were not on a jury, but the comments were 
  overheard by a defendant.Â  
Challenges alleging prosecutorial misconduct typically 
  involve a prosecutorâ€™s improper efforts to collect evidence or unfair trial 
  tactics.Â  See, e.g., State v. Quattlebaum, 338 S.C. 441, 
  527 S.E.2d 105 (2000) (assistant solicitor viewed the surreptitious videotaping 
  of privileged attorney-client communication); State v. Huggins, 325 S.C. 
  103, 481 S.E.2d 114 (1997) (prosecutor discussed matters outside of the evidence 
  during closing arguments); State v. Chisolm, 312 S.C. 235, 439 S.E.2d 
  850 (1994) (prosecutor improperly audiotaped telephone conversation with defendant, 
  who was represented by counsel); State v. Robinson, 305 S.C. 469, 409 
  S.E.2d 404 (1991) (prosecutor allegedly used previously suppressed evidence 
  at trial); State v. Atkins, 303 S.C. 214, 399 S.E.2d 760 (1990) (prosecutor 
  allegedly obtained confidential medical records in violation of attorney-client 
  privilege); State v. Pee Dee News Co., 286 S.C. 562, 336 S.E.2d 8 (1985) 
  (prosecutor asked improper questions at trial); State v. Craig, 267 S.C. 
  262, 227 S.E.2d 306 (1976) (prosecutorâ€™s conduct at trial allegedly was calculated 
  to arouse unfair prejudice against defendant).Â  
Because Huttoâ€™s claim appears to be novel, counsel 
  attempts to analogize the circumstances to the more typical case where a prosecutor 
  makes improper statements before a jury.Â  We do not accept the comparison.Â  
  Our judicial system prohibits such comments because they urge the jury to base 
  its verdict on something other than the evidence.Â  Such a rationale is not warranted 
  in the present case.Â  
Even if the solicitor made the alleged comments, 
  they did not abrogate Huttoâ€™s due process rights in the same manner as would 
  comments to a jury.Â  The comment was directed not to Hutto but to law enforcement.Â  
  Because the solicitor had already stated in open court that he intended to seek 
  life without parole, it is unclear how the statement could have hampered Huttoâ€™s 
  efforts to seek the courtâ€™s mercy in its sentence. Â Although Huttoâ€™s 
  mother stated in her affidavit that she thought the solicitorâ€™s comment kept 
  Hutto from testifying at the sentencing hearing, Hutto has offered no similar 
  claim.
We reject Huttoâ€™s contention that the solicitorâ€™s 
  statements denied him due process. 
  [2] 
II.Â  Inadmissibility of Evidence 
  During Sentencing
Hutto also argues the trial court should not have 
  allowed the solicitor to introduce the out-of-court statements of the jailhouse 
  informant and the two juvenile residents of the Rimini facility as the prejudicial 
  impact of the statements outweighed any probative value.Â  See Rule 403, 
  SCRE.
We are not concerned with balancing prejudicial 
  impact with probative value when reviewing evidence used in the sentencing phase 
  of a non-capital crime because evidentiary rules are inapplicable in a sentencing 
  proceeding.Â  Rule 1101(d)(3), SCRE; State v. Gulledge, 326 S.C. 220, 
  228-29, 487 S.E.2d 590, 594 (1997); see also Williams v. New 
  York, 337 U.S. 241 (1949).Â  In sentencing a convicted defendant a trial 
  court is only limited by constitutional provisions that require the evidence 
  to be relevant, reliable and trustworthy.Â  See Gulledge, supra.
The court stated in its order denying resentencing 
  it took into account the statements were those of convicted criminals whose 
  credibility was not wholly reliable.Â  However, the court noted the statements 
  were corroborated by both the physical facts of the crime and similar statements 
  by Huttoâ€™s co-defendant.Â  The court reasoned â€œ[i]t would have been impossible 
  for the jailhouse informant to fabricate the conversations which he had with 
  [Hutto] so as to mirror almost exactly portions of the testimony given by [Huttoâ€™s 
  co-defendant].â€Â  
In short, the trial court properly considered the 
  challenged statements because they were corroborated. The statements were both 
  relevant and reliable.
AFFIRMED.
 HOWARD and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]    We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to 
    Rule 215, SCACR.

 
   [2]    Huttoâ€™s counsel alludes to a violation of the Rules 
    of Professional Conduct when he suggests the solicitorâ€™s comments were directed 
    towards a defendant represented by counsel out of counselâ€™s presence.Â  See 
    Rule 407, SCACR, Rule 4.2, RPC (â€œ[A] lawyer shall not communicate about the 
    subject of the representation with a party the lawyer knows to be represented 
    by another lawyer in the matter . . . .â€).Â  Huttoâ€™s allegation is not that 
    the solicitor attempted to converse with him about the case outside the presence 
    of counsel.Â  Instead, Hutto alleges he overheard a conversation between the 
    solicitor and other law enforcement.Â  We fail to see how even a liberal application 
    of the rule would prohibit such comments.
