THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Paul Sherman, Appellant/Respondent,
v.
W & B Enterprises, Inc., Respondent/Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Orangeburg County
Olin D. Burgdorf, Master-in-Equity

Opinion No. 3701
Heard June 12, 2003 â€“ Filed November 24, 2003

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED
IN PART, AND REMANDED 
__________

  
    
      
Gerald F. Smith and James B. Richardson, Jr., both 
  of Columbia, for Appellant-Respondent.
Thomas B. Bryant, III, of Orangeburg, for Respondent-Appellant.
      
    
  


BEATTY, J.:Â  These cross-appeals arise from 
  a suit Sherman brought against W & B Enterprises, Inc. (W & B) alleging 
  breach of contract and violation of the Payment of Post-Termination Claims to 
  Sales Representatives Act, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 39-65-10 to -80 (Supp. 2002).Â  Sherman 
  sought commissions for sales W & B made to K-Mart during his tenure with 
  W & B.Â  Following a non-jury trial in the circuit court, the trial court 
  awarded Sherman the commissions he sought, but only for orders delivered before 
  W & B terminated him.Â  Additionally, the trial court refused to award Sherman 
  attorney fees.Â  
Sherman appeals.Â  He argues the trial courtâ€™s finding 
  he is not entitled to commissions for sales made to K-Mart before his termination, 
  but not delivered, is erroneous.Â Â  He further argues the trial court erred in 
  failing to award him attorney fees under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 39-65-10 to -80 (Supp. 
  2002), contending such a statutory award is mandatory.Â  In a cross-appeal, W 
  & B argues the trial court erred in finding it entered an oral contract 
  with Sherman.Â  We affirm in part and reverse in part.
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  FACTS/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Sherman joined W & B as a sales representative 
  in either 1992 or 1993.Â  Initially, he represented two accounts, Southern States 
  and Wal-Mart stores.Â  His agreement with W & B provided he would receive 
  a ten percent commission on all sales he made to Southern States and a five 
  percent commission on all sales he made to Wal-Mart.Â  
In September 1993, Sherman contacted Joe 
  Antonini, the president and chief executive officer of K-Mart Corporation (K-Mart).Â  
  Antonini and Shermanâ€™s brother had been fraternity brothers in college, through 
  which Sherman became familiar with Antonini.Â  In his letter, Sherman sought 
  to sell W & Bâ€™s products to K-Mart stores.Â  In response to the letter, Antonini 
  promptly had a K-Mart merchandise buyer contact Sherman regarding the prospect 
  of a business relationship, which soon developed.Â  After a small test order 
  in 1994 succeeded, Sherman proceeded to sell approximately $5 million to $6 
  million of W & Bâ€™s merchandise to K-Mart in 1995.Â  He received a commission 
  of three percent of these sales from W & B.Â  
After a dispute with W & B, 
  Sherman resigned in late 1996.Â  The following spring, W & B made overtures 
  to Sherman in an effort to resume their business relationship.Â  He returned 
  to the company in March or April of 1997, on the condition that, among other 
  things, he receive a three percent commission on all K-Mart sales.Â  
W & B made no sales to K-Mart in 1997.Â  
  Sherman, along with Jeffrey Watford, a son of W & Bâ€™s owner Woody Watford, 
  met with K-Mart buyers in 1998 about resuming their business relationship.Â  
  As a result, W & B received â€œsome ordersâ€ for merchandise from K-Mart in 
  1998.Â  
 In the meantime, Sherman was increasing 
  his sales to Wal-Mart, and began spending more time on the account.Â  Consequently, 
  Jeffery Watford increased his role in W & Bâ€™s sales relationship with K-Mart.Â  

Sherman discovered in January 1999 that 
  his commission on K-Mart orders had been reduced to two percent.Â  No agreement 
  had been made to reduce his commission from three percent.Â  After Sherman brought 
  the change to W & Bâ€™s attention, Watford assured Sherman he would receive 
  the balance due to make his compensation equal to three percent of his sales 
  to K-Mart.Â  W & B also failed to pay Sherman any commission on the Valentineâ€™s 
  Day 2000 sale to K-Mart, but not shipped until after W & B terminated Sherman.Â  
  Sherman would have earned an $18,960.48 commission on that sale, based on a 
  three percent rate of commission.Â  
II.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Shermanâ€™s Appeal
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  A.      
Issues

  
    
      
        1. 
         Did the circuit court err in finding that Sherman 
  was not entitled to receive a commission on the K-Mart order booked before his 
  employment was terminated but not shipped until afterwards?
      
      
        2.
         Did the circuit court err in holding that the 
  award of an attorneyâ€™s fee to the prevailing party under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 39-65-30 
  (Supp. 2001) is discretionary rather than mandatory?
      
    
  

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
B.       Standard of Review
An action for breach of contract 
  is an action at law.Â  Roberts v. Gaskins, 327 S.C. 478, 483, 486 S.E.2d 
  771, 773 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  An ordinary suit to recover attorney fees is also 
  an action at law.Â  Weatherford v. Price, 340 S.C. 572, 578, 532 S.E.2d 
  310, 313 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  â€œIn an action at law, on appeal of a case tried without 
  a jury, the findings of fact of the judge will not be disturbed upon appeal 
  unless found to be without evidence which reasonably supports the judgeâ€™s findings.â€Â  
  Townes Assocs., Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 
  773, 775 (1976).Â  â€œThe rule is the same whether the judgeâ€™s findings are made 
  with or without a reference.â€Â  Id.Â  The judgeâ€™s findings are equivalent 
  to a juryâ€™s findings in a law action.â€Â  Id.

C.      Law/Analysis
  
1.    Commissions
  

Sherman maintains no evidence exists 
  in the record to support the trial courtâ€™s finding that he was not entitled 
  to receive a commission on orders booked before his employment ended but not 
  shipped until afterward.Â  We agree.
This issue concerns the trial courtâ€™s 
  decision not to award Sherman a commission for the Valentineâ€™s Day 2000 sale.Â  
  In its order, the trial court stated:

It is standard practice in the industry to only pay commissions 
  when goods are shipped as quite often orders are changed, sometimes cancelled 
  and the transaction is effectively not completed until shipment.Â  As a result, 
  [Shermanâ€™s] claim on the Valentineâ€™s Day 2000 order, being shipped after [Sherman] 
  left [W & B], would not be covered.

However, the record contains no evidence to support 
  the trial courtâ€™s finding that this is a â€œstandard practice in the industry.â€Â  
  In fact, the record indicates that W & Bâ€™s practice was just the opposite, 
  since W & B undisputedly paid Sherman commissions on Wal-Mart accounts for 
  sales he made before he was terminated that were not delivered until after his 
  termination.Â  

2.    Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Sherman contends that an award 
  of reasonable attorney fees to the prevailing party is mandatory under S.C. 
  Code Ann. Â§ 39-65-30 (Supp. 2001).Â  We agree.

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  The relevant South Carolina statutes 
  in this case regarding post-termination claims to sales representatives provide:

When a contract between a sales representative and a principal 
  is terminated for any reason, the principal shall pay the sales representative 
  all commissions that have or will accrue under the contract to the sales representative 
  according to the terms of the contract.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 39-65-20 (Supp. 2002).â€¦

A principal who fails to comply with the provisions of Section 
  39-65-20 is liable to the sales representative in a civil action for:
(1) All amounts due the sales representative plus punitive 
  damages in an amount not to exceed three times the amount of commissions due 
  the sales representative; and
  (2) attorneyâ€™s fees actually and reasonably incurred by the sales representative 
  in the action and court costs.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 39-65-30 (Supp. 2001) (emphasis 
  added).Â  
Sherman contends the use of the language â€œis liableâ€ 
  makes the attorneyâ€™s fee provision of this statute mandatory, rather than within 
  the trial courtâ€™s discretion.Â  
â€œThe cardinal rule of statutory construction is 
  that we are to ascertain and effectuate the actual intent of the legislature.â€Â  
  Burns v. State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co., 297 S.C. 520, 522, 377 S.E.2d 
  569, 570 (1989).Â  â€œThe words of a statute must be given their plain and ordinary 
  meaning without resorting to subtle or forced construction to limit or expand 
  a statuteâ€™s operation.â€Â  Elmore v. Ramos, 327 S.C. 507, 510-511, 489 
  S.E.2d 663, 665 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  The â€œuse of the word â€˜mayâ€™ signifies permission 
  and generally means that the action spoken of is optional or discretionary unless 
  it appears to require that it be given any other meaning in the present statute.â€Â  
  Kennedy v. South Carolina Ret. Sys., 345 S.C. 339, 352-53, 549 S.E.2d 
  243, 250 (2001).
Here, the statuteâ€™s use of the term â€œis liable,â€ 
  instead of â€œmay be liableâ€ reflects a mandate rather than an option.Â  Thus, 
  we find that the statuteâ€™s language providing â€œ[A] principal who fails to comply 
  with the provisions of Section 39-65-20 is liable to the sales representative 
  in a civil action for â€¦ attorneyâ€™s fees actually and reasonably incurred by 
  the sales representative in the action and court costsâ€ can only reasonably 
  be construed to mandate an award of attorney fees where a violation of the statute 
  is found.Â  Accordingly, we find the circuit court erred in failing to award 
  reasonable attorneyâ€™s fees and related costs pursuant to the statute, and remand 
  for further proceedings to determine the amount of attorneyâ€™s fees and expenses 
  to which Sherman is entitled.
III.Â Â Â  W & B Enterpriseâ€™s Appeal

A.     
Issue 
  
Did the circuit court err in finding an oral contract 
  existedÂ Â  between Sherman and W & B?
  

        
B.       Standard of Review 
When the existence of a contract 
  is questioned and the evidence either conflicts or gives rise to more than one 
  inference, the issue of the contractâ€™s existence becomes a question for the 
  finder of fact.Â  See Small v. Springs Indus., Inc., 292 S.C. 481, 
  483, 357 S.E.2d 452, 454 (1987) (stating that under the common law, a trial 
  court should submit to the jury the issue of existence of a contract when its 
  existence is questioned and the evidence either conflicts or admits of more 
  than one inference).Â  â€œIn an action at law, on appeal of a case tried without 
  a jury, the findings of fact of the judge will not be disturbed upon appeal 
  unless found to be without evidence which reasonably supports the judgeâ€™s findings.â€Â  
  Townes Assocs., Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 
  773, 775 (1976).Â  â€œThe judgeâ€™s findings are equivalent to a juryâ€™s findings 
  in a law action.â€Â  Id.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
C.       Law/Analysis
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  W & B argues Sherman failed 
  to prove he formed an oral contract with W & B.Â  We disagree.
Although the record conflicts, Sherman testified 
  that he and Watford, Sr., agreed that Sherman would be paid a full three percent 
  commission on K-Mart orders after he resumed working for W & B.Â  Further, 
  Sherman was in fact paid three percent commission on some of the K-mart orders.Â  
  This provides â€œany evidenceâ€ to support the trial courtâ€™s findings that W & 
  B and Sherman agreed to compensate Sherman at a rate of three percent in commissions 
  for sales W & B made to K-Mart after Sherman returned to W & B in 1998.Â  
  Although Shermanâ€™s testimony conflicts with other evidence in the record, our 
  standard of review only allows us to look for the existence of evidence, 
  and not to weigh its credibility.Â  Accordingly, we find evidence to support 
  the trial courtâ€™s finding that Sherman and W & B entered an oral contract, 
  and affirm the circuit courtâ€™s finding on this matter.
CONCLUSION
For the forgoing reasons, the decision 
  of the circuit court is
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, and REMANDED.
HOWARD, J., and JEFFERSON, A.J., concur.
